1 APRIL.part4: For Thou, O LORD of hosts, God of Israel, hast revealed to Thy servant, saying, I will build thee an house: therefore hath Thy servant found in his heart to pray this prayer unto Thee.
1 APRIL.part5:
David's desire to build a house for the Lord was at first endorsed by prophet Nathan. But God's revealed will and message for David through Nathan was rather the opposite - "The Lord telleth thee, that He will make thee an house" [v. 11b]. It was not God's will for David to build the Temple. Instead, God promised David that He would build a house for him and establish the Davidic kingdom forever. The holy privilege to build the Temple was not David's but his seed's [v. 12-13]. Solomon was God's choice for the task.

In response to God's word, David poured out his soul in prayer [v. 18-26]. Expressing profound gratitude for the promised blessings, David did not presume the right to God's goodness. He did not take them for granted but expressed a sense of unworthiness in his prayer. David was bold in prayer because he knew God was faithful to every promise He makes.

David's prayer boldness reminds us to pray confidently trusting in God's faithfulness in keeping His Word. God has given us exceeding great and precious promises by which we may plead with Him. God will fulfil His promises according to His written Word because God cannot deny Himself and He cannot lie. With confidence in His faithfulness "let us therefore come boldly unto the throne of grace, that we may obtain mercy, and find grace to help in time of need" [Hebrews 4:16]. Our Heavenly Father knows our need and will faithfully provide. Our part is to ask with humble, contrite and believing hearts.
1 APRIL.part7: For all the promises of God in Him are yea, and in Him Amen, unto the glory of God by us. - 2 Corinthians 1:20

2 APRIL.part4: And now, O Lord GOD, Thou art that God, and Thy words be true, and Thou hast promised this goodness unto Thy servant:
2 APRIL.part5:
Not only is God faithful to provide, David cited three other infallible reasons to pray with boldness, which are for our instruction today.

First - "Thou art that God" - by nature God is immutable. "For I am the LORD, I change not therefore ye sons of Jacob are not consumed" [Malachi 3:6]. God cannot and does not change. Hebrews 13:8 tells us that "Jesus Christ the same yesterday, and today, and for ever". People change, and things change in looks, values, qualities, but God never changes. He preserves us through the storms of life. Therefore, remembering His immutability, we can echo the confidence of Psalm 46:1. "God IS our Refuge and strength, a very PRESENT help in trouble" (emphasis added).

Second - "and Thy words be true" - David cast his hope on the Lord's Word because he believed them to be true. It reminds us of a greater David who was to come. Our Lord Jesus in His high priestly prayer declared - "Thy word is truth" [John 17:17b]. Truly we rejoice with the psalmist in praising God for the truthfulness of His Word - "Thy word is true from the beginning: and every one of Thy righteous judgements endureth for ever" [Psalm 119:160].

Third - "Thou hast promised this goodness unto Thy servant" - David not only believed the promised goodness of God's Word, he also had confidence in the reliability of God's promises.

This is the message for us. Our God is immutable. He is good. His Word is absolutely reliable for our faith and daily practice. We can depend on it. So we echo the psalmist's prayer - "Remember Thy word unto Thy servant, upon which Thou hast caused me to hope" [Psalm 119:49].
2 APRIL.part7: The Westminster Shorter Catechism says that "God is a spirit, whose being, wisdom, power, holiness, justice, goodness, and truth are infinite, eternal, and unchangeable."

3 APRIL.part4: Therefore now let it please Thee to bless the house of Thy servant, that it may continue for ever before Thee: for Thou, O Lord GOD, hast spoken it: and with Thy blessing let the house of Thy servant be blessed for ever.
3 APRIL.part5:
David not only believed God, the blessings of His word, he was also confident of the reliability of His promises and their fulfillment. His closing words: "Therefore now let it please Thee to bless the house of Thy servant" - would confirm his earlier ones in verse 25: "And now, O LORD God, the word that Thou hast spoken concerning Thy servant, and concerning his house, establish it for ever, and do as Thou hast said." By calling upon the Lord to carry out His promises, David believed the declaration: "God is not a man, that He should lie; neither the son of man, that He should repent: hath He said, and shall He not do it? or hath He spoken, and shall He not make it good?" [Numbers 23:19]. The answer is obvious. To call upon the Lord to fulfil His promises is asking Him to do it. It is not asking amiss but for His glory to be manifested.

At the same time, we should remember that God has His timing and plan in carrying out His promises. We learn from David's example to "trust in the LORD, and do good ... rest in the LORD, and wait patiently for Him" [Psalm 37:3a, 7a]. Our part is not only to anticipate the Lord fulfilling His promises, we are also to make sure we do good. That means we continue to submit ourselves to the Lord, wait upon Him in prayer and occupy ourselves by obeying His Word. To that end, David instructed us to "delight thyself also in the LORD; and He shall give thee the desires of thine heart" [Psalm 37:4]. Indeed, God will do it for His glory.
3 APRIL.part7: And call upon Me in the day of trouble: I will deliver thee, and thou shalt glorify Me. - Psalm 50:15

4 APRIL.part4: Therefore now let it please Thee to bless the house of Thy servant, that it may continue for ever before Thee: for Thou, O Lord GOD, hast spoken it: and with Thy blessing let the house of Thy servant be blessed for ever.
4 APRIL.part5:
Up to this point, David's life had been eventful to say the least - from shepherd boy to giant- slayer; from being well-favoured by the people to a fugitive fleeing from the king. Though there were occasions when he could have killed Saul and seized the throne, he would not lay his hand against the "anointed of the LORD" [1 Samuel 24:6].

With the death of Saul, David's years of wandering and hiding in the Judaean desert had finally come to an end. He was first crowned king of Judah at Hebron in the south [2 Samuel 5:3]. However, a power struggle and civil war ensued between David and Ish-bosheth - youngest of Saul's four sons, and the only one who survived him. But the real power behind Ish-bosheth was his uncle, Abner. Ish-bosheth ruled Israel from his capital at Mahanaim, on the east of Jordan [2 Samuel 2:8-9]. His reign lasted only two years, and Ish-bosheth was brutally murdered by his guard.

David was anointed king over Israel, and "David went on, and grew great, and the LORD God of hosts was with him" [2 Samuel 5:10]. After consolidating his position, and securing the nation by defeating the Philistines, David turned his attention to spiritual matters. The first thing on his mind was to relocate the Ark of the Covenant from Gibeah to Jerusalem. The event was black-marked when Uzzah was struck down by the LORD for handling the Ark. When it was finally brought back to Jerusalem, his joy was dampened by his wife, Michal, who despised him for his dancing, which perhaps in her eyes was unbecoming of a king.

After years of ups and downs in David's life, there was finally peace [2 Samuel 7:1]. God would establish the Davidic covenant [2 Samuel 7:12-15].
4 APRIL.part7: God is sovereign, and He is good. "And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to His purpose" [Romans 8:28].

5 APRIL.part4: And after this it came to pass, that David smote the Philistines, and subdued them: and David took Metheg-ammah out of the hand of the Philistines.
5 APRIL.part5:
2Samuel 8 records the victories of David in his wars against Israel's enemies. Without these decisive victories, David's reign could never be truly secure because these enemies surrounded Israel. The Philistines were located on the west, the Moabites [v. 2] to the east. The threats from the north came from the king of Zobah and Syrians [v. 3]. And to the south was Edom [v. 13-14].

David set his sight first on the Philistines who were hardened enemies of Israel. The Philistines were constantly launching attacks into Israel, and although they were able to repel these, they could never completely put them down until David reigned. Before David, the Philistines were always the aggressor. But now, David launched the attack, entering their territory and conquering Metheg- ammah.

In the parallel account - 1 Chronicles 18:1 - Methegammah was actually, or a part of, the city of Gath. Gath was built upon the hill Ammah, and called Metheg-ammah, which means "bridle of Ammah" implying it was a well-fortified city, which served as a bridle upon the Israelites.

Gath's most famous citizen was Goliath; it was also the city of giants [2 Samuel 21:18-22]. And it was where David sought refuge in his early years as a fugitive [1 Samuel 21:10]. But now David "smote the Philistines, and ... took Metheg-ammah out of the hand of the Philistines", opening the way to decisively subdue them.

The same can be said of our breakthrough from sin to salvation. The strongholds of sin must be broken down so that God can have full rein on our lives. By His power, God destroyed the "strong holds ... bringing into captivity every thought to the obedience of Christ" [2 Corinthians 10:4-5].
5 APRIL.part7: Take my life and let it be, consecrated, Lord, to Thee. Take my heart, it is Thine own, it shall be Thy royal throne. - Frances Havergal

6 APRIL.part4: And he smote Moab, and measured them with a line, casting them down to the ground; even with two lines measured he to put to death, and with one full line to keep alive. And so the Moabites became David's servants, and brought gifts.
6 APRIL.part5: After defeating the Philistines, David turned east against Moab. The relationship between the Israelites and Moabites was bitter-sweet. Bitter because one of the most famous Moabite was Balak - the king of Moab - who bribed Balaam to curse Israel [Numbers 22:4-6; 25:1-3]. Despite that hostile act, God commanded them to "distress not the Moabites, neither contend with them in battle: for I will not give thee of their land for a possession" [Deuteronomy 2:9]. However, after the Israelites had conquered and settled in Canaan, the Moabites frequently attacked them [Judges 3:12-30; 1 Samuel 14]. Sweet because of David's personal relationship with them. First, he sought the help of the king of Moab to protect his parents when their lives were in danger [1 Samuel 22:3-4]. Second, there was actually Moabite blood flowing through David's veins. David's great-grandmother was Ruth who was a Moabitess [Ruth 4:20-22]. Yet David marched against Moab. The phrase "he ... measured them with a line, casting them down to the ground" refers to the defeated Moabite soldiers who were made to lie on the ground, and two thirds of them were executed. Why was the judgement so severe? According to Jewish tradition, it was David's revenge against Moab's king who had put David's parents to death. The severity of David's action was also intended to cripple and subjugate the Moabites, making it impossible for them to take up arms again, thus reducing Moab to a vassal state. Likewise, for our Christian walk to be victorious, we must also bring our flesh into subjection to the greater David, our Lord Jesus.
6 APRIL.part7: Paul says, "I keep under my body, and bring it into subjection: lest that by any means, when I have preached to others, I myself should be a castaway." [1 Corinthians 9:27].

7 APRIL.part4: David smote also Hadadezer, the son of Rehob, king of Zobah, as he went to recover his border at the river Euphrates.
7 APRIL.part5:
David's third conquest brought him farther afield to Zobah, which was a Syrian province extending from the eastern slopes of Lebanon in the north and east toward the Euphrates. The history of hostilities between Zobah and Israel dated back to the reign of King Saul [1 Samuel 14:47].

This would be the first of two wars David fought against Zobah [2 Samuel 10:6]. Verse 3 tells us that the goal was to recover territory. In the first war, David faced off with Hadadezer, king of Zobah, and won a great victory, capturing "a thousand chariots, and seven hundred horsemen, and twenty thousand footmen: and David houghed all the chariot horses, but reserved of them for an hundred chariots" [2 Samuel 8:4].

To hough (pronounced "hock") a horse is to hamstring it by severing the tendons of the hind legs thus rendering them useless for war. The word is also translated several ways "digged down" [Genesis 49:6]; "pluck up" [Ecclesiastes 3:2]; "rooted up" [Zephaniah 2:4]. By the houghing and uprooting processes, the life source of a thing and its ability to grow strong is cut off.

God had commanded the king of Israel not to "multiply horses to himself, nor cause the people to return to Egypt, to the end that he should multiply horses" [Deuteronomy 17:16]. The reason is so they would not rely on the power of horses and chariots for their strength. The spiritual lesson of houghing is to keep the people of God from placing confidence in anything or anyone other than the LORD [Psalm 20:7; 33:16-17].
7 APRIL.part7: What do you trust? "Some trust in chariots, and some in horses: But we will remember the name of the LORD our God." [Psalm 20:7]

8 APRIL.part4: And when the Syrians of Damascus came to succour Hadadezer king of Zobah, David slew of the Syrians two and twenty thousand men. Then David put garrisons in Syria of Damascus: and the Syrians became servants to David, and brought gifts. And the LORD preserved David whithersoever he went.
8 APRIL.part5:
As David and his army moved east toward the Euphrates, they encountered the Syrian army that had allied with Hadadezer, king of Zobah. The additional Syrian forces were, however, no match for David; the children of Israel routed the enemy. "David slew of the Syrians two and twenty thousand men" [v. 5]. Victory over the Syrians also gave David control over Damascus, and "David put garrisons in Syria of Damascus" [v. 6].

Garrisons were units of military forces [1 Samuel 10:5; 1 Chronicles 11:16] that were stationed at strategic locations to prevent enemy incursions and protect a country's border. It is derived from the Hebrew verb "to stand".

There are a few connotations that can be derived from this word. First, a garrison is a picture of territorial boundaries that God has established. The Psalmist says God "hast set all the borders of the earth" [Psalm 74:17]. God "divided to the nations their inheritance ... He set the bounds of the people according to the number of the children of Israel" [Deuteronomy 32:8; Proverbs 15:25]. The lesson is that God has also set the moral boundaries for His people. There are lines - marked out by the Law of God - that believers must not cross.

Second, a garrison is also a picture of firmness - physical health as well as spiritual vigour. In Psalm 39:5, David says that "every man at his best state is altogether vanity." David is making the point that if we, even the best of us, are to stand on our own, our lives will be futile. But David adds, "As for me, Thou upholdest me in mine integrity, and settest me before Thy face for ever" [Psalm 41:12]. It is the LORD who enables us to stand.
8 APRIL.part7: God has given us the means - the whole armour of God - so "that ye may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done all, to stand" [Ephesians 6:13].

9 APRIL.part4: Then David put garrisons in Syria of Damascus: and the Syrians became servants to David, and brought gifts. And the LORD preserved David whithersoever he went.
9 APRIL.part5:
Hamath was named after one of the sons of Canaan [Genesis 10:18], which meant that it was one of the oldest cities in the world. It was one of the cities the 12 spies came to when they went out to survey the land [Numbers 13:21]. A fortified city in the north, near Mount Hermon [Joshua 13:5; Judges 3:3], Hamath was one of the few places in Syria that retained a certain degree of importance from the earliest times to David's time.

As the news of David's conquest over the Philistines, Moabites and the Syrians spread, Toi, king of Hamath, had to make a decision - go to David with a peace offering and become a vassal state, or go to war against the powerful Israelite army and face certain defeat. He wisely chose the former. "Toi sent Joram his son unto king David, to salute him, ... And Joram brought with him vessels of silver, and vessels of gold, and vessels of brass" [v. 10].

Verses 6 and 14 give the key to David's success - "The LORD preserved David whithersoever he went." The word "preserved" is translated in several ways - "helped" [Exodus 2:17], "saved' [Exodus14:30], "delivered" [Judges 2:16], and also as "being victorious" as in Psalm 98:1, where the Psalmist praises the LORD because "He hath done marvellous things: His right hand, and His holy arm, hath gotten Him the victory."

David had proven himself to be a mighty warrior, unmatched in warfare and courageous in battle. However, the key to his success was not his natural qualities of leadership, but that "the LORD preserved David whithersoever he went". As long as we are walking with God and doing His will, we will be watched and guarded by the LORD whom we serve.
9 APRIL.part7: As we serve God, we are surrounded by the impenetrable shield of His grace. Consider Psalm 37:23-24, 28.

10 APRIL.part4: And Joram brought with him vessels of silver, and vessels of gold, and vessels of brass: which also king David did dedicate unto the LORD, with the silver and gold that he had dedicated of all nations which he subdued.
10 APRIL.part5:
The spoils of war are often tempting. David was presented with "vessels of silver, and vessels of gold, and vessels of brass" [v. 10b] but he kept none for himself. He dedicated the treasures unto the LORD.

To dedicate something is to hallow it; to make it holy. It is also translated "to sanctify" [Exodus 13:2]. It is mostly used of things being set apart for use in the Lord's worship, such as the altar [Exodus 29:21, 37]. When something is dedicated to the LORD, it belongs to God, and cannot be used by any other.

The dedication of the gold and silver would mean that David placed the treasures in some sacred treasury for the present services in the tabernacles and perhaps for the future construction of the temple. While David was forbidden by God to build the temple [2 Samuel 7:4-12; 1 Chronicles 22:8; 28:3], he began to stockpile the materials which his son, Solomon, would use to build it [1 Chronicles 28:14-18; 29:1-5].

In dedicating the gold and silver to the LORD, David exemplified true piety and whole-hearted devotion. In Paul's sermon, he said David "served his own generation by the will of God" [Acts 13:36]. And while he did not live to see the completion of the temple, David had the long-term perspective of his calling. He saw that the work of God was larger than himself and would extend beyond his lifetime. Like David, we dedicate our all to the LORD, serve Him to our best in this present life, and leave a legacy for others to continue the work.
10 APRIL.part7: We do not have to see in this life the fruit for which we labour. "And he that reapeth receiveth wages, and gathereth fruit unto life eternal: that both he that soweth and he that reapeth may rejoice together. And herein is that saying true, One soweth, and another reapeth" [John 4:36-37].

11 APRIL.part4: And Joram brought with him vessels of silver, and vessels of gold, and vessels of brass: which also king David did dedicate unto the LORD, with the silver and gold that he had dedicated of all nations which he subdued.
11 APRIL.part5:
When David first proposed building the temple, Nathan said to him, "Go, do all that is in thine heart; for the LORD is with thee" [2 Samuel 7:3]. But David was not given the privilege to build God's temple because he was a man of war and had shed much blood [1 Chronicles 28:3]. Though disqualified from building it, and the actual construction was left to Solomon, the LORD took into account David's consecration. At the dedication of the Temple, Solomon said, "The LORD said to David my father, Forasmuch as it was in thine heart to build an house for My name, thou didst well in that it was in thine heart" [2 Chronicles 6:8].

The dedication of the heart is the first step to our service for the LORD; it is really the consecration of self. All true godliness must begin with the surrender of self - the will, mind, strength and affection of body and soul to God so that He can sanctify and use us for His glory. No other gift - regardless of material value - matters without dedication of the heart. No gift can be a substitute for heart dedication. No other gift will be acceptable without it.

Our Lord Jesus compared the giving of the wealthy, who gave out of their abundance, to the poor widow who gave her two mites, He said, "she of her want did cast in all that she had, even all her living" [Mark 12:44]. Even though she could not give as much as the wealthy did in absolute terms, our Lord Jesus honoured her because it came from her heart. The wealthy gave their spare change; the widow's "small" gift was all she had.
11 APRIL.part7: True offerings to God are the offerings of His true servants.

12 APRIL.part4: And Joram brought with him vessels of silver, and vessels of gold, and vessels of brass: which also king David did dedicate unto the LORD, with the silver and gold that he had dedicated of all nations which he subdued.
12 APRIL.part5:
David dedicated the gold and silver to the LORD because he had first dedicated himself to the LORD. The former is a natural outflow of the latter. When we realise all that we are is the result of the LORD's doing, then we will also realise all that we have is of the LORD's giving. David demonstrated this truth when he prayed, "Both riches and honour come of Thee ... But who am I, and what is my people, that we should be able to offer so willingly after this sort? for all things come of Thee, and of Thine own have we given Thee" [1 Chronicles 29:12-14].

When the believers in Jerusalem were suffering famine, Paul initiated a collection to help in the relief of the Jewish converts. The Macedonian Christians were the first and most eager to give, more than the wealthier Corinthians. In fact, Paul wrote that the Macedonians themselves were "in a great trial of affliction". However, "their deep poverty abounded unto the riches of their liberality" [2 Corinthians 8:2]. Paul testified that they were willing to give beyond their own means to the point that they were pleading with Paul to receive their gift so they might have a part in ministering to the saints.

What was the reason for the generous giving by these poor Macedonians? Paul said they "first gave their own selves to the Lord, and unto us by the will of God" [2 Corinthians 8:5]. The lesson is that what we have gained by work and enterprise, what we have been given, and all that we are, must be dedicated to God for His glory.
12 APRIL.part7: You are a steward who has all things and yet owns nothing. Read 1 Timothy 6:17.

13 APRIL.part4: And David gat him a name when he returned from smiting of the Syrians in the valley of salt, being eighteen thousand men.
13 APRIL.part5:
The exact location of the valley of salt is not known, but it was the place where Israel won two important victories over the Syrian and Edomite armies. The first, recorded in our text today, was David's army slaying 18,000 enemy soldiers. It seemed that the Edomites, seeing David engaged in a war with the Syrians, took the opportunity to invade Israel. But the allied Syrian-Edomite forces were no match for David [1 Chronicles 18:12]. The second victory happened some 200 years later when Amaziah, king of Judah, slew 10,000 Edomites and seized their capital Selah, changing its name to Joktheel [2 Kings 14:7; 2 Chronicles 25:11].

There are a number of publications entitled Who's Who, containing brief biographical information of prominent people in various fields - sports, business, politics, etc. David, in a sense, received mention in the Who's Who. From his victories, David "gat him a name", meaning he made a name for himself; his reputation and fame were greatly increased. Many names were made in war and conquests; example: Alexander the Great, Genghis Khan, Napoleon Bonaparte, etc. Some made theirs through achievements, others through notoriety. It is better to be unknown than to have an infamous name. Better still it is to be unknown by the world and known only by the Creator of this world.

David was celebrated as a warrior by his admirers [1 Samuel 18:7], hated by his enemies for the same reason [1 Samuel 21:11]. But to God, David was "a man after His own heart". I wonder which of these David would want to be known by? What kind of name would you have?
13 APRIL.part7: A good name is rather to be chosen than great riches, and loving favour rather than silver and gold. - Proverbs 22:1

14 APRIL.part4: And David gat him a name when he returned from smiting of the Syrians in the valley of salt, being eighteen thousand men.
14 APRIL.part5: David "gat him a name" - he became famous. His son, Solomon, also got himself a name. He is known for his wisdom. The Queen of Sheba was so impressed after visiting Solomon she told him, "Thy wisdom and prosperity exceedeth the fame which I heard" [1 Kings 10:7b]. A good name must reflect reality. It is worthless for a person to have a name conferred by others through flattery. It is even worse for one to acquire a name for himself for the sake of vanity. And the worst of all is for one to present oneself as good and pious when one is not. The Pharisees made themselves known for their piety, they "make broad their phylacteries, and enlarge the borders of their garments, and love the uppermost rooms at feasts, and the chief seats in the synagogues, and greetings in the markets, and to be called of men, Rabbi, Rabbi" [Matthew 23:5-7], but our Lord Jesus called them hypocrites. They are like the Church at Sardis, which our Lord Jesus Christ says "hast a name that thou livest, and art dead" [Revelation 3:1b]. There is inestimable value in a good name, but only if there is evidence that testifies to its truth. As a Christian, we bear the Name of Christ. However, the reality and authenticity of the name is not by what we claim to be; rather it is proven by the content of our character. So, rather than trying to gain a name for ourselves, let us labour instead to be accepted of God in the Beloved, and He will take care of our reputation among men.
14 APRIL.part7: Live up to the Name of Christ, and He will lift up our name for His glory.

15 APRIL.part4: And David reigned over all Israel; and David executed judgement and justice unto all his people.
15 APRIL.part5:
The secret of David's success was because "the LORD preserved David whithersoever he went" [v. 14]. God surrounded him like a shield that no dart could pierce. In the past, all the javelins Saul hurled never came close to David. From David, we see that if we are committed to following God, giving ourselves over to Him, doing His will, serving Him, and having nothing but the thought of pleasing Him, the LORD will guard our every step [Psalm 37:23-24].

After his wars and victories, David must now begin the work of ruling the country. He had gone through several years dealing with the house of Saul [2 Samuel 3:1]. The civil conflict revealed Israel really to be a loose confederation of tribes. The challenge before David was to unite the people. To his credit, David "executed judgment and justice unto all his people." "All his people" would include his supporters as well as those who initially did not give him their whole-hearted support.

David won them over not by forced submission but by judicious action. "David executed judgement" - this means that David was "doing justice". He was fair and equitable. He did not favour those who were for him, and turn against those who were not for him. Likewise, when we execute judgement, we treat every person as he is. David executed justice (righteousness) - this speaks of David's actions as well as his conduct.

A righteous person will do the right thing the right way. Applying this truth to our salvation, God's righteousness not only means judgement on our sin, but also the gift of His only begotten Son as the solution to our sin problem.
15 APRIL.part7: Give the king Thy judgments, O God, and Thy righteousness unto the king's son. He shall judge Thy people with righteousness, and Thy poor with judgement. - Psalm 72:1-2

16 APRIL.part4: And David said, Is there yet any that is left of the house of Saul, that I may shew him kindness for Jonathan's sake?
16 APRIL.part5:
The friendship between David and Jonathan came about partly because of king Saul's envious hostility against David. Jonathan believed God had anointed David to be Israel's king. He knew it was wrong for his father to oppose God by trying to destroy David. Jonathan had a holy fear of God. He knew that God's kingdom through the house of David would soon replace Saul's line. Undoubtedly Jonathan loved his father and he was also concerned that his family and the descendents of Saul would not be preserved when David eventually took over the kingdom.

Hence, Jonathan made a covenant with David [1 Samuel 20:16]. The details are given in 1 Samuel 20:42: "And Jonathan said to David, Go in peace, forasmuch as we have sworn both of us in the name of the LORD, saying, The LORD be between me and thee, and between my seed and thy seed for ever." They pledged loyalty to one another in a covenantal relationship between their two families. And David, the man after God's own heart, would honour his pledge. For Jonathan's sake, David was committed to show kindness to the house of Saul.

As believers we have a covenantal relationship of grace in our Lord Jesus Christ with one another. As brethren in the same household of faith we are duty bound to show love, kindness and care for one another. We are to eschew self-seeking, evil speaking, anger, hatred, bitterness and such. And where we have failed, we must repent, get right with God and continue to serve God together with joy.
16 APRIL.part7: And be ye kind one to another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake hath forgiven you. - Ephesians 4:32

17 APRIL.part4: And there was of the house of Saul a servant whose name was Ziba. And when they had called him unto David, the king said unto him, Art thou Ziba? And he said, Thy servant is he.
17 APRIL.part5:
Following his ascension to the throne, David demonstrated his kindness to the house of Saul. The practice in those days was for the new king to massacre anyone related to the family of the erstwhile hostile monarch. Mephibosheth, son of Jonathan and natural heir to Saul would be in great danger of his life. But David instead of seeking to kill, sought to bless. He would show kindness to the household of Jonathan with whom he had a covenant.

It was David who took the initiative. He sought information concerning Jonathan's surviving kin. The search found Ziba who revealed to David that Mephibosheth, Jonathan's lame son, was in hiding. And David would show kindness to Mephibosheth for "Jonathan's sake" which was the "kindness of God" manifested through the king [v. 1b, 3a].

This reminds us of our helpless estate as wretched, depraved sinners undeserving of the least of God's mercies. Yet, God sovereignly sought us and saved us by His grace. At one time we were dead in sin and without hope. But we thank God that out of His covenantal loving-kindness, He sent His only begotten Son, our Lord Jesus Christ to save us. Our Lord gave His life on the cross as the perfect sacrifice for our sins. He called us to turn to Him through the Gospel and by the power of the Holy Spirit, we repented from our sins and were marvellously saved. We cannot thank God enough for His saving grace, His sustaining grace and His abundant grace that ensure we, His blood-bought children, are kept in His service for His glory and praise.
17 APRIL.part7: According as He hath chosen us in Him before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and without blame before Him in love. - Ephesians 1:4

18 APRIL.part4: And there was of the house of Saul a servant whose name was Ziba. And when they had called him unto David, the king said unto him, Art thou Ziba? And he said, Thy servant is he.
18 APRIL.part5:
Ziba, the servant of King Saul, had fifteen sons and twenty servants [v. 10]. With the demise of Saul's sons save for lame Mephibosheth now living under the patronage of Machir in Lo Debar, we can safely infer that Ziba had free rein over Saul's estates as its steward and overseer, and enjoyed much authority and privilege in the absence of any oversight. Furthermore it is evident he was an astute and capable man who had prospered, with many sons and even servants under him.

Now summoned by King David for information about Saul's surviving family, the shrewd steward was able to perceive that his comfortable status quo could be threatened. And as the story unfolds, it will be seen that Ziba proves to be a crafty duplicitous schemer who manoeuvres his way into gaining what was rightfully Mephibosheth's [2 Samuel 16:3-4]. Ziba achieved what his covetous heart sought and certainly in society's eyes would be regarded a smart and successful man. "The ends justify the means" is the world's mantra.

But that is not the way of our Lord Jesus Christ. Honesty is the Christian's badge. He speaks the truth without prevarication. He tolerates neither guile nor deceit in his heart because it pollutes the temple of the Holy Spirit [1 Corinthians 6:19]. The ninth commandment is his rule which forbids him bearing false witness, misrepresenting truth or speaking lies to achieve his desired ends.

Ziba is an example of what a servant should not be, especially for us who are servants of the living God and ambassadors for our Lord Jesus Christ.
18 APRIL.part7: To be truthful is to be most Christ-like, therefore "... let your communication be, Yea, yea; Nay, nay: for whatsoever is more than these cometh of evil" [Matthew 5:37].

19 APRIL.part4: And the king said, Is there not yet any of the house of Saul, that I may shew the kindness of God unto him?
19 APRIL.part5:
David held all power in his hand. Mephibosheth deserved nothing apart from the kindness of the king. And it is in the keeping of David's covenant with Jonathan that we are given a veiled look at the kindness of God toward undeserving man.

What is the kindness of God? The word "kindness" here is the great Hebrew word of Old Testament grace - "hesed". Variously translated "loving-kindness, mercy, goodness, steadfast love", it encompasses all of these and more, for it speaks of the special covenant relationship undergirding all these elements which binds Jehovah to his chosen people. And it is an everlasting and unbreakable covenant made and upheld by the eternal, sovereign and faithful God.

To whom does He extend such kindness? In all ages, it has been to whomsoever who will receive it - any repentant and contrite sinner, unclean and unworthy who recognises his need to be saved from his sin and accepts Him alone who can save. "But as many as received Him, to them gave He power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on His name." [John 1:12]. Salvation is a free gift of God received only by faith. It is the gift of son-ship whereby the slave of sin becomes the child of God.

Mephibosheth dined henceforth at the king's table as his subject but those days would come to an end. We who are recipients of God's "hesed" will dine at the Father's table as sons and daughters for all eternity never to hunger or thirst again.
19 APRIL.part7: This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners; of whom I am chief. - 1 Timothy 1:15

20 APRIL.part4: And the king said, Is there not yet any of the house of Saul, that I may shew the kindness of God unto him? And Ziba said unto the king, Jonathan hath yet a son, which is lame on his feet.
20 APRIL.part5:
Mephibosheth merited no favours from his sovereign save for the promise that bound David and his father years before. Now Jonathan was gone and David held sway over Israel. Easy it would have been for him to forget and forgo the words of a distant past. But the king whom God had blessed much would now love much in his gratitude and obedience to God. So David sought out Mephibosheth.

We are all Mephibosheths at heart, full of flaws and defects, but God sought us out to show His kindness too. Like the crippled son, we have been shown the unmerited goodness and grace of God because the loving Father sent His beloved and sinless Son, the Greater David, to be our Saviour and satisfaction for divine holiness and justice, to accomplish what we, who were dead in sin and condemned, could not do for ourselves. What a sublime picture of God's covenantal love towards His chosen!

What then are we to be, being such recipients of grace? We are to manifest God's love in turn by our love for others, even our enemy. We are to bless them, pray for and do good to them and overcome evil with good.

Kindness must be the adornment of God's people and the principle by which we live. Our every thought, word and deed must be the fruit of kindness. Paul enjoined the Colossians to "put on therefore, as the elect of God, holy and beloved, bowels of mercies, kindness, humbleness of mind, meekness, longsuffering" [Colossians 3:12]. Our Lord Jesus Himself told His disciples, "Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these My brethren, ye have done it unto Me" [Matthew 23:40]. Let us so do.
20 APRIL.part7: Every little act of kindness, even a cup of water given in our Lord's name, is recognised in heaven. Read Matthew 25:34-45.

21 APRIL.part4: Then king David sent, and fetched him out of the house of Machir, the son of Ammiel, from Lo-debar.
21 APRIL.part5:
Machir was a wealthy sheikh of one of the Transjordanic (West of River Jordan) tribes living in Lo-debar in Gilead. By some accounts he was also a Benjamite.

After Saul's death, his sole surviving but crippled son Mephibosheth would live under the roof and care of this benefactor. Scant mention is made of this man in Scripture but the little that is said reveals much about his heart. The only other place we meet Machir is when the fortunes of David had turned and he was in Gilead fleeing from his usurper son Absalom. In 2 Samuel 17: 27-29, we see another beautiful and spontaneous act of kindness by Machir in provisioning David and his followers unstintingly with implements for comfort and food from the rich produce of his land.

Machir is an example of the compassion and kindness that should characterise God's people. There was certainly neither need nor gain for him to take Mephibosheth under his charge. There was nothing Mephibosheth could conceivably do for him, since Saul was dead and David was king. There was also no gain but only possible loss in succoring David, when Absalom looked to have the upper hand in his challenge for the throne.

Machir's motivation to act was simply the recognition of need and the opportunity presented for him to do good. That must be all the more so with us who have received the Lord's goodness. The person in need is our neighbour to whom we must extend our Christian love and kindness. Did not our Lord Jesus say, "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind; and thy neighbour as thyself " [Luke 10:27].
21 APRIL.part7: And now abideth faith, hope, charity, these three; but the greatest of these is charity. - 1 Corinthians 13:13

22 APRIL.part4: And David said unto him, Fear not: for I will surely shew thee kindness for Jonathan thy father's sake, and will restore thee all the land of Saul thy father; and thou shalt eat bread at my table continually.
22 APRIL.part5:
With the kingdom now stabilised, David turned his attention to the welfare of Jonathan's remaining household. David's kindness to Mephibosheth was motivated by his gratitude for God's kindness and to honour the covenant he had made with Jonathan [1 Samuel 20:14-15]. Jonathan had protected David from his father and had been a loving and faithful friend when David was friendless in Saul's court.

Mephibosheth presented himself before David fearfully but the king addressed him with gentleness. He assured Mephibosheth his intention to show him kindness for Jonathan's sake. He would restore to him all the land his family had forfeited because of his uncle Ishbosheth's rebellion. Furthermore, Mephibosheth would be invited to eat continually at David's table. David promised Mephibosheth protection, possessions and provisions. Mephibosheth was crippled from childhood and now living in obscurity away from Jerusalem. Yet King David sought him and in kindness and mercy, restored him and treated him as a son.

We, at one time, were spiritually wretched, lame and helpless in our lost estate. The greater David, our Lord Jesus out of great love for us, left heaven's glory, came down to earth and sought after us. He suffered and died for our sins to gain for us salvation so rich and free and restored our fellowship - lost by our first earthly father, Adam in his rebellion - to God our Heavenly Father. He made us His children, "heirs of God and joint heirs with Christ" [Romans 8:17], and granted us peace, protection and provision. What marvellous love! Amazing Grace!
22 APRIL.part7: Bless the LORD, O my soul: and all that is within me, bless His holy name. Bless the LORD, O my soul, and forget not all His benefits. - Psalm 103:1-2

23 APRIL.part4: And he bowed himself, and said, What is thy servant, that thou shouldest look upon such a dead dog as I am?
23 APRIL.part5:
Though a prince in his own right, Mephibosheth had spent his childhood and young adult life in abject helplessness, obscurity and misery after the death of his father and grandfather, relying on the charity of Machir. Now, he found himself in the King's palace. Struck by the awesome sight of the King and palace surroundings, he bowed in reverence. David was touched by the humility of his dear friend's son and showered kindness upon him. Shocked and perplexed, Mephibosheth in humility and self-abasement wondered aloud why such a "servant" and "dead dog" as he should deserve such kindness. David the Psalmist on another occasion had similarly enquired this of God about himself [Psalm 8:4].

God in His sovereign will and counsel had allowed the things which had befallen Mephibosheth. When Divine power brings one down it is not without accompanying Divine grace. In due time God would lift up Mephibosheth again and restore him to his royal position.

David himself had manifested humility. When Saul deceitfully offered his daughter Merab to be David's wife, David declared his own unworthiness [1 Samuel 18:18]. David had even bowed to Jonathan [1 Samuel 20:41]. God oftentimes humbles us for our own spiritual good. Mephibosheth, on seeing David's greatness, goodness and magnanimity, was greatly moved. It is only when we envision the height of Divine greatness and goodness, that we realise the depth of our own unworthiness and shame. And so it was with Isaiah when he saw the holiness of God and was ashamed of his own uncleanness and unworthiness [Isaiah 6:5]. "By humility and the fear of the LORD are riches, and honour, and life." [Proverbs 22:4].
23 APRIL.part7: Humble yourselves in the sight of the Lord, and he shall lift you up. - James 4:10

24 APRIL.part2: David's charge to Ziba and Ziba's commitment
24 APRIL.part4: Thou therefore, and thy sons, and thy servants, shall till the land for him, and thou shalt bring in the fruits, that thy master's son may have food to eat: but Mephibosheth thy master's son shall eat bread alway at my table. Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.
24 APRIL.part5:
Having pronounced restoration of Saul's properties to Mephibosheth, David charged Ziba, his sons and servants to till the land and ensure that the whole household of Mephibosheth including the servants would be provided for. Ziba, a long-time servant of Saul would have accumulated much wealth and substance for himself as evidenced by his own large household. With much privileges, Ziba would now carry the responsibility to provide for the entire house. "When goods increase, they are increased that eat them: and what good is there to the owners thereof, saving the beholding of them with their eyes?" [Ecclesiastes 5:11]. Not only was Mephibosheth saved from his previous wretchedness, he was restored all that was rightfully his and more - a place in David's house.

Salvation is paradise regained. We are reconciled to God our Heavenly Father once again. With salvation so great, rich and free, comes much blessings and privileges. We are justified and adopted into God's family. With privilege comes responsibility. We are called to holiness as God our Father is holy [1 Peter 1:15-16], to walk worthy of the vocation wherewith we are called [Ephesians 4:1], to put off the old man and put on the new, to care one for another [Ephesians 4:22-32]. We must bear the Fruit of the Spirit [Galatians 5:22] and cleanse ourselves to be fit vessels for the Master's use, as servants and ambassadors, bearing to the lost the good news of salvation and reconciliation [2 Corinthians 5:20]. We are called to be soldiers of our Lord Jesus Christ fighting a good fight for Him, contending earnestly for the faith, till He comes again.
24 APRIL.part7: I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service. - Romans 12:1

25 APRIL.part4: Then said Ziba unto the king, According to all that my lord the king hath commanded his servant, so shall thy servant do. As for Mephibosheth, said the king, he shall eat at my table, as one of the king's sons.
25 APRIL.part5: David not only restored to Mephibosheth all the confiscated properties of Saul, David decreed that Mephibosheth would eat at his table as one of his sons. Mephibosheth, orphaned from the age of five, was now taken into the family of David who would be like a father to him. Not only would Mephibosheth be assured of abundant food and provisions, he would be in constant communion with David, as a son communing with a father. He would enjoy the security, love and warmth of the family. Though lame and of no useful service, he would not be an embarrassment at the dinner table because the king welcomed him. Our Heavenly Father loved us with such a great love. In His compassion, mercy and grace, He gave us the matchless gift of His Son, our Lord Jesus, to reconcile us back unto Himself and made us His sons and daughters [2 Corinthians 6:18]. He sustains us by providing for all our needs. God has graciously given us His Holy Word upon which we can nourish our soul in faith, love, hope and holiness. As we eat of the bread and drink of the wine at the Lord's Supper in remembrance of our Lord Jesus, we look forward to the day when we will dine with Him, the King of kings, in Heaven even as He has promised [Revelation 3:20]. We shall see Him face to face [Revelation 20:4] and commune with Him. The feast will be one of perfect joy, peace and rest and we will be with Him forever. All who have accepted the invitation of the Gospel will be present at the King's table.
25 APRIL.part7: Blessed is he that shall eat bread in the kingdom of God. - Luke 14:15

26 APRIL.part4: Then said David, I will shew kindness unto Hanun the son of Nahash, as his father shewed kindness unto me. And David sent to comfort him by the hand of his servants for his father. And David's servants came into the land of the children of Ammon.
26 APRIL.part5:
The Ammonites were descendants of Lot through his incestuous relationship with his younger daughter after the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah. They lived east of the Jordan River.

They had a reputation as cruel people known to slice open pregnant women in battle [Amos 1:13]. Ammon did not have a friendly relationship with Israel and even threatened to thrust out the right eye of every man in Jabesh-gilead [1 Samuel 11:1-2] to subjugate them as servants in exchange for peace. The people of Jabesh-gilead were saved when Saul led the Israelite army to defeat the Ammonites.

Nahash the King of Ammon had shown David kindness in an act that was unrecorded in the Bible. Upon Nahash's death, David would show his gratitude for that kindness, sympathy to the grieving family and congratulations to his son, the new king. The transition in political leadership brought uncertainty to the ties between Israel and Ammon. David hoped to continue the good relationship he had with the old king by comforting the new. Just as David had shown kindness and mercy to Jonathan's family by providing for Mephibosheth, David desired to show kindness to the family of Nahash. David, the man after own God's heart, sought to undergird his conduct of domestic affairs and foreign policy with mercy and kindness.

God's Word teaches us to treat others with kindness, mercy and honesty, to show our Christian love. Indeed, it is by such expressions and actions that we reflect God's love for mankind and perhaps win them to the Lord Jesus Christ.
26 APRIL.part7: Put on therefore, as the elect of God, holy and beloved, bowels of mercies, kindness, humbleness of mind, meekness, longsuffering. - Colossians 3:12

27 APRIL.part4: And the princes of the children of Ammon said unto Hanun their lord, Thinkest thou that David doth honour thy father, that he hath sent comforters unto thee? hath not David rather sent his servants unto thee, to search the city, and to spy it out, and to overthrow it?
27 APRIL.part5:
Hanun's national security council was staffed by evil men lacking in wisdom, love and magnanimity. Their hatred for Israel intensified after their earlier defeat by Saul. They felt insecure seeing David and Israel prosper and increase in strength. This made them distrust David and view his kind actions with great suspicion.

They jumped to the conclusion that Israel's king was sending ambassadors to spy out their land and city. They assumed these ambassadors were there to gather intelligence, valuable in helping them lay siege on their city in the future. This reflected their suspicious minds and contempt for King David, and the evil in their heart, which lead them to give their king bad advice.

We must not be conceited in thinking we have perfect understanding of every motive behind people's actions. The existence of any slightest dislike of a person will cause us to misjudge their friendly intentions. They may have meant us good, but we interpret their intent to be bad. Many a quarrel has erupted over such misunderstandings and many relationships have been broken. A careful examination of our opinions of others may reveal ungodly thoughts for which we must seek forgiveness.

May God teach us to resist the evil influence that blinds us to the good in people, to think evil of them and harbour ill-will towards another. Let us pray God will teach us to love others and bestow His wisdom upon us so we will respond in a God- honouring manner even if others think evil of us.
27 APRIL.part7: Charity suffereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up, Doth not behave itself unseemly, seeketh not her own, is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil. - 1 Corinthians 13:4-5

28 APRIL.part4: Wherefore Hanun took David's servants, and shaved off the one half of their beards, and cut off their garments in the middle, even to their buttocks, and sent them away.
28 APRIL.part5:
Middle-eastern men grow beards as a sign of wisdom, gravity and manhood. To shave off one side of their beards is an indignity comparable to flogging and branding. Other than the priesthood, men in biblical times did not wear undergarments, so cutting their clothes down the middle to their buttocks would expose their nakedness. Hanun's actions were designed to cause maximum humiliation as his people ridiculed these ambassadors and drove them out of Ammon. The insults were not directed at these men alone but at Israel and her king. Hanun not only threw away the opportunity to strengthen his kingdom by aligning with David, his rejection of David's friendly gesture signalled defiance and a provocation to war.

Mankind's response to God's gift of His only begotten Son, our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, is no different. In the Parable of the Vineyard [Matthew 21:33-46], the husbandmen representing the Jewish religious leaders, rejected the servants (Old Testament prophets) and finally killed the son (our Lord Jesus Christ) of the vineyard owner (God the Father). Many people reject our Lord even though they hear in the Gospel message that He came in love and mercy to save them from their sins. In their pride and wilful hard-heartedness, they do not think they have sinned, nor do they need the Saviour. Like the Jewish religious leaders, they drove our Lord Jesus out of their lives and crucify Him, yet deny any wrong-doing.

Do not treat God's gift of salvation with contempt. Do not reject our Lord Jesus. Come to Him in humility and repent of your sins. Only He can cleanse and forgive us of our sins.
28 APRIL.part7: For the Son of man is come to save that which was lost. - Matthew 18:11

29 APRIL.part4: And when the children of Ammon saw that they stank before David, the children of Ammon sent and hired the Syrians of Bethrehob, and the Syrians of Zoba, twenty thousand footmen, and of king Maacah a thousand men, and of Ishtob twelve thousand men.
29 APRIL.part5: Ammon had become so odious in Israel's eyes, yet Hanun refused to make amends. He even thought it would be a good idea to go to war with them. The Bible does not reveal the size of the two armies, but it is clear that Hanun thought they stood a better chance of defeating Israel if they had help. Therefore, he enlisted the services of 33,000 Syrian mercenaries. The Syrians were no doubt eager to crush Israel which was increasing in strength since David's ascension to the throne. The combined Ammonite-Syrian army was a formidable force that would test the military capabilities of the Israelites and their faith in God. When we do the Lord's work, do we count on numbers as well? Are we discouraged that our church is small and our members less wealthy than others? Do we think souls can only be won when we have trendy programmes and charismatic leaders in our ministries to draw the crowds in? Do we surrender because our efforts do not bear much spiritual fruit? Let us not be misled by modern theories of church growth and worldly philosophies. Spiritual victories are not won by large armies of church-goers relying on their strength, intelligence and capabilities. Numbers do not guarantee or even indicate spiritual success. The Bible records how Israel won battles facing numerically superior enemies because they understood the need for God's work to be done in God's way, trusting Him wholly. May we learn to rely on God's wisdom and strength to do His work because His grace is sufficient for us [2 Corinthians 12:9].
29 APRIL.part7: The Christian life is often a battle against Satanic opposition and all God's work is spiritual warfare, but the battle and victory is His, so that no flesh can claim any glory. "And all this assembly shall know that the LORD saveth not with sword and spear: for the battle is the LORD'S, and He will give you into our hands" [1 Samuel 17:47].

30 APRIL.part4: And when David heard of it, he sent Joab, and all the host of the mighty men.
30 APRIL.part5:
The men of Ammon having humiliated David's ambassadors, now hired Syrian mercenaries and arrayed themselves to do battle. David himself had only told his humiliated servants to tarry at Jericho. While the humiliation of his envoys was an affront to him, there is no indication he was planning a military operation against those evil men. He may have been willing to leave the matter in the hands of the Almighty God, to judge them in His time.

"O LORD God, to whom vengeance belongeth; O God, to whom vengeance belongeth, shew Thyself. Lift up Thyself, thou Judge of the earth: render a reward to the proud" [Psalm 94:1-2].

Now however, the Ammonites not only sought to go to war, but also assembled a formidable force, employing Syrian mercenaries to do battle alongside them. David's hand is now forced, and to ignore the clear and present threat, would be a foolish and irresponsible act, placing him and his people in danger of being annihilated. He was forced to respond.

David sent Joab and his host of mighty men. Joab whose name means "Jehovah is father" was a trusted military commander and ardent supporter of David. He had his personal failings, but David could trust him with this military task. The phrase "host of mighty men" implies an organised army of able warriors. "Host" is also used to describe the angels and celestial bodies (sun, moon and stars) all of which are in the service of God.
30 APRIL.part7: Look to God for wisdom to know when to be patient and when to act decisively. Look to God and He will direct your paths.

1 MAY.part4: And he said, If the Syrians be too strong for me, then thou shalt help me: but if the children of Ammon be too strong for thee, then I will come and help thee.
1 MAY.part5:
Joab saw two battle lines formed against him: before and behind [v. 9]. He chose the best soldiers to be under his direct command against the Syrians who were in the field. It is likely these Syrians were formidable fighters and the reason why the Ammonites had employed them. The remaining host of Israel were put under his brother Abishai's command, and their primary task was to engage the Ammonite army assembled in front of their city (likely Rabbah). In the event of collapse of either Israelite force, the other would come to their aid. The fact that Joab had to divide his army suggests he recognised he was unable to maintain a prolonged battle on two fronts. He had to plan for contingencies, and being humble enough to realise this, turned to his brother for help.

"Two are better than one; because they have a good reward for their labour. For if they fall, the one will lift up his fellow: but woe to him that is alone when he falleth; for he hath not another to help him up" [Ecclesiastes 4:9-10].

We see that while everyone must endeavour to do their best for God, we must also realise we are not alone. Often, God sends like-minded co- labourers to work alongside us. Be sensitive to the Holy Spirit's leading and be humble to acknowledge that cooperation with those whom God sends, is God's will to allow us to do well for His glory.
1 MAY.part7: And he that reapeth receiveth wages, and gathereth fruit unto life eternal: that both he that soweth and he that reapeth may rejoice together. And herein is that saying true, One soweth, and another reapeth. - John 4:36-37

2 MAY.part4: Be of good courage, and let us play the men for our people, and for the cities of our God: and the LORD do that which seemeth Him good.
2 MAY.part5:
Joab and Abishai were about to fight a battle not of their choosing. The Ammonites had humiliated King David's envoys then arrayed their army together with Syrian mercenaries. Israel's army was facing a battle on two fronts against a numerically superior force. They resolve to be of good courage. To "play the men for our people" is to show themselves to be strong. They are in effect girding themselves spiritually for battle - knowing they must be strong and show themselves to be so. They spoke not just to themselves but to encourage their men. They were standing up in defence of their people and cities which were not just theirs, but God's. They were fighting to prevent Jehovah's people and cities falling under heathen oppression. They were resolved to win for they saw themselves as agents for a greater cause - God's glory.

"Whether therefore ye eat, or drink, or whatsoever ye do, do all to the glory of God" [1 Corinthians 10:31]. Joab showed himself unscrupulous and unprincipled in other circumstances, yet recognised he was fighting for God here. He was able to declare that the outcome was in God's hands.

We see that both faith in God's sovereignty and wisdom must be present in His people to do His work. Joab made wise plans in splitting his forces, resolved to be strong and displayed strength in battle, and yet trust the outcome to God. Earnestly labour for God yet trusted Him for the outcome of our labour. This is the complementary operation of God's sovereignty and man's responsibility.
2 MAY.part7: I have planted, Apollos watered; but God gave the increase. So then neither is he that planteth any thing, neither he that watereth; but God that giveth the increase. - 1 Corinthians 3:6-7

3 MAY.part4: And Joab drew nigh, and the people that were with him, unto the battle against the Syrians: and they fled before him.
3 MAY.part5:
The plan was conceived for a battle they had not sought, and to defend God's possession. The heart was resolved to be strong for God's people. Their eyes were looking to God in faith, entrusting Him with the outcome of the battle. The moment of action arrived, and Joab stepped forward to do the work. After every preparation and plan has been done, there is the need to act. Joab and his mighty men drew near the enemy in battle, and the Syrians "fled before him". They approached to engage, and their opponents took flight. This outcome could not have been predicted by any human reasoning or logic. When the Ammonites saw the Syrian mercenaries on the run, they too fled before Abishai's men into their city [v. 14]. Before Joab and his men moved, they had prepared and prayed calling on God for His blessing. Bless them He did, and in a manner far exceeding their hopes [Jeremiah 33:3]. It was by God's hand that the enemy was destroyed.

"How should one chase a thousand, and two put ten thousand to flight, except their Rock had sold them, and the LORD had shut them up?" [Deuteronomy 32:30]

The Syrians fled like the hirelings they were, and while the Israelites were being faithful to God in this instance, it is God who is the ever faithful covenant- keeping God to His people. God is keeping His promise to the Israelites as they continued walking in His commandments [Leviticus 26:1-9]. Praise God for His promises are true!
3 MAY.part7: Now unto Him that is able to do exceeding abundantly above all that we ask or think, according to the power that worketh in us, unto Him be glory in the church by Christ Jesus throughout all ages, world without end. Amen. - Ephesians 3:20-21

4 MAY.part4: And when it was told David, he gathered all Israel together, and passed over Jordan, and came to Helam. And the Syrians set themselves in array against David, and fought with him.
4 MAY.part5:
When David learned that Hanun's father, Nahash king of Ammon died, he sent his servants to comfort Hanun out of goodwill. Instead of being grateful, Hanun shaved off half the beards, cut half the clothes of the delegates and ridiculed them. According to the customs then, in mistreating and humiliating David's men in that manner, Hanun in effect declared war unilaterally and unprovoked. What a way to repay kindness and concern! Hanun thought he would win because he engaged able Syrian mercenaries. David had no choice but to go to war. He led the fight together with Joab. And God delivered the victory to them.

As Christians, we desire to preach the Gospel, the Good News that our Lord Jesus saves. Like David's servants, we mean well. Our aim is to tell of the way to get to Heaven. Instead, many Christians are persecuted, scorned, ridiculed and some have even been put in jail or killed for just preaching and sharing the Gospel. The world spits in defiance at the Good News and spurns the great gift. In effect, many have declared war with God the Giver. And we are engaged in this spiritual battle but God fights alongside us. He will deliver the victory as He had to David.

This reminds us of our Lord Jesus Christ who came to save man. How was He treated? He was not welcomed. "He came unto His own, and His own received Him not" [John 1:11]. Instead, the world despised, persecuted, and finally crucified Him. But our Lord Jesus defeated His enemy, the Devil. He conquered death and rose from the dead. He is the Victor. Nobody can go up against God and expect to triumph.
4 MAY.part7: The horse is prepared against the day of battle: but safety is of the LORD. - Proverbs 21:31

5 MAY.part4: And when all the kings that were servants to Hadarezer saw that they were smitten before Israel, they made peace with Israel, and served them. So the Syrians feared to help the children of Ammon any more.
5 MAY.part5:
The Ammonites and Syrians were no match for David because God was with the Israelites. The Syrians no longer wanted to help the Ammonites after being defeated. They now made peace with Israel and served them. Why did the Syrians do an about turn to make peace with Israel and not to continue helping the Ammonites? They knew that the Almighty God has been merciful and gracious to David and Israel. Although David had a strong and mighty army, it was God who gave the victory. As God told Paul, we only hurt ourselves if we kick against the pricks.

It is in the best interest for the Syrians to make peace with the Jews. Like the Syrians, we cannot struggle our way through and hope to win the battle against sin and death. We should stop, surrender our will to God and seek peace. Then God will give us real peace in our life. Do not wait until you lose a war to make peace with God. Our Lord Jesus gives this inner peace that nobody else can. There is peace of mind and there is peace in the heart. We have the assurance our Lord is with us at all times. He will guide every step in our walk with Him. We can face even terminal illness with confidence because we know that after we leave this earth, our Lord Jesus will be waiting for us in Heaven. He reserves a place there for everyone who believes and accepts Him as his Saviour. Turn to God and make peace with Him. Our Lord Jesus Christ is the Prince of Peace.
5 MAY.part7: Or let him take hold of My strength, that he may make peace with Me; and he shall make peace with Me. - Isaiah 27:5

6 MAY.part3: VERSE 1 gone with his army in the siege of Rabbah.
6 MAY.part4: And it came to pass, after the year was expired, at the time when kings go forth to battle, that David sent Joab, and his servants with him, and all Israel; and they destroyed the children of Ammon, and besieged Rabbah. But David tarried still at Jerusalem.
6 MAY.part5:
David led the war against the Ammonites and Syrians. Though the Jews won that battle, the war was not over. The Israelites continued to besiege Rabbah. Instead of staying with the soldiers, David went back to his home in Jerusalem. As their leader and king, David should have stayed on to give the moral support and lead. However, he preferred the comfort of his home. David would not have been tempted by sin (which Scripture records) if he had gone with his army in the siege of Rabbah.

Christians should be always busy for the Lord. We are to be grateful since God delivered us out of darkness and gave us eternal life. Is it too much for us to use our time and talents to serve Him? Both our time and talents are from Him. Without God, we have nothing.

Perhaps David wanted to be with his soldiers, but his flesh was weak. "Watch and pray, that ye enter not into temptation: the spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak" [Matthew 26:41]. Our Lord Jesus encourages us to watch and pray so we do not enter into temptation. If we are busy for the Lord, we are likely to have less opportunity for temptation to get the better of us. There are many ways and places to serve and be busy for the Lord. Like David, we may be willing to serve but our flesh is weak. We are to avail ourselves for God, to use our talents, time, and treasures for His Glory. The only question is - Are we willing?

7 MAY.part4: And David sent and enquired after the woman. And one said, Is not this Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?
7 MAY.part5:
In this world, temptation lurks at every corner. Oftentimes, we may not even be actively seeking trouble, but trouble comes along and finds us. This was the case with David as well. He was doing something completely innocuous - strolling on his roof garden and viewing the scenery. However, temptation soon came knocking. He spotted Bathsheba bathing. This was when David sinned. Instead of fleeing the temptation, he allowed sin to gain a foothold in his heart. First, he passively remained on the roof and continued watching her. Next, he exacerbated the temptation by actively inquiring after the woman so he could indulge his sinful lust.

This negative example is for us to learn from. First, when put in situations where sin is lurking at the door, we should not remain passive. The Apostle Paul instructed Timothy, "Flee ... youthful lusts" [2 Timothy 2:22]. Likewise, we should take decisive action to flee and remove ourselves from that situation so that we do not allow sin to creep in and stay. We are to run away from sin.

Second, there should be a conscious effort to be "simple concerning evil" [Romans 16:19]. There is absolutely no need to "find out more" about the temptation that is beckoning us. While we may be curious, be reminded of the young man in Proverbs 7, who perhaps out of curiosity, passed by the strange woman's house and was subsequently ensnared in sin. We are to stay away from sin.

Finally, instead of entertaining the tempting sights and sounds, let us remember to cleave to that which is good [Romans 12:9]. We are to run to God instead.
7 MAY.part7: It is not enough to flee from temptation. We need to run to God.

8 MAY.part3: VERSE 5 sin is to conceal it. Adam hid from God, and David,
8 MAY.part4: And the woman conceived, and sent and told David, and said, I am with child.
8 MAY.part5:
David went from entertaining temptation to falling headlong into sin. As he allowed lustful covetousness to gain ground in his heart, the prospect of committing adultery with Bathsheba became more and more enticing. Soon he forgot about God and His call for holiness and succumbed.

The natural reaction of a person who falls into sin is to conceal it. Adam hid from God, and David, as we will read in following verses, would take elaborate measures to cover up his sin. The lesson for us is that no matter how well hidden it may be, "your sin will find you out" [Numbers 32:23; 1 Corinthians 4:5]. We may hide our sin from the people around us, but we will never be able to hide our sin from the all-seeing God.

God is omniscient Who knows our every thought, word, and deed. It is vanity and foolishness to think that we can indulge our sinful nature without His knowledge. More importantly, we have to realise that there are consequences to our sin. The direct consequence of David's adultery was Bathsheba's pregnancy. Now David had to cover that up and suffer the mental anguish of pretending that all was well.

In this manner, David's heart was being hardened. We must realise it is time to quickly and humbly seek forgiveness from the Lord, when it is obvious that we are facing the consequences of our sin. In trusting his own strength and devices to conceal his sin from God and man, David would eventually end up committing murder.
8 MAY.part7: If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness. - 1 John 1:9

9 MAY.part4: And the woman conceived, and sent and told David, and said, I am with child.
9 MAY.part5:
What a direct statement Bathsheba makes here. She had broken her marriage vow to her husband Uriah. Now she must face the unwanted consequence of her adultery.

David had to face the consequences of his sin as well. How do you feel about David at this point? Not only was his weak human nature revealed, but his sinful nature was also exposed. David had chosen to remain behind in Jerusalem. He had sent Joab to lead the army against Ammon in the conquest of Rabbah. Instead of leading his army as he usually did, David stayed back and acted without seeking God's guidance.

Now we see David and Bathsheba trying to figure a way out of this unwanted pregnancy. Bathsheba knew the penalty for adultery. David, as Israel's king, could not escape punishment too. In fact, it would be more severe for him as he was the one who sought out and enticed Bathsheba. Had he sought God for strength to overcome his lustful desire, this would not have happened.

Sin will always lead to more sin when we choose to persist unrepentantly down that path. It is a downward slide to more and more selfish misdeeds. One idle moment of watching Bathsheba led to lust, covetousness, adultery and murder. How true the inspired words of Scripture - "But every man is tempted, when he is drawn away of his own lust, and enticed. Then when lust hath conceived, it bringeth forth sin: and sin, when it is finished, bringeth forth death" [James 1:14-15].

10 MAY.part3: VERSE 6 David's act would be covered up.
10 MAY.part4: And David sent to Joab, saying, Send me Uriah the Hittite. And Joab sent Uriah to David.
10 MAY.part5:
We see David hatching his clever cover-up. Note the details of his elaborate and stealthy plan. Joab obeyed the king's order unquestioningly. David pretended to seek a report of the battle from Uriah, then sent him home to Bathsheba to spend the night with food and drink, expecting the battle-worn soldier to seek the company and loving arms of his wife. If that had transpired, then there would be a cause for Bathsheba's pregnancy and David's act would be covered up.

But as we shall see, one lie often leads to another in order to cover up the first. This is the downward slide of sin, and if a sinner does not stop what he is doing and turn back to God, he will sink deeper and deeper into sin's quagmire, which Bunyan in Pilgrim's Progress fittingly calls the Slough of Despond. The unrepentant sinner sinks hopelessly under the weight of his sin and guilt to a certain death. Hence James warned - "But every man is tempted, when he is drawn away of his own lust, and enticed. Then when lust hath conceived, it bringeth forth sin: and sin, when it is finished, bringeth forth death" [James 1:14-15].

Better it would have been for David to repent, confess and make right with God. Repentance leads to God's forgiveness and forgiveness leads to His restoration. The consequences of sin would have to be borne but they would be mitigated. And this is true for us as well when we fall into temptation and sin.
10 MAY.part7: Draw nigh to God, and He will draw nigh to you. Cleanse your hands, ye sinners; and purify your hearts, ye double minded. - James 4:8
