11 MAY.part3: VERSE 11 sin did not work. He feigned concern for Uriah the
11 MAY.part4: And Uriah said unto David, The ark, and Israel, and Judah, abide in tents; and my lord Joab, and the servants of my lord, are encamped in the open fields; shall I then go into mine house, to eat and to drink, and to lie with my wife? as thou livest, and as thy soul liveth, I will not do this thing.
11 MAY.part5:
David wanted Uriah to spend the night with his wife. But the loyal and faithful soldier cared more for his men than his pleasure. What a contrast to David! Instead of going home to Bathsheba's arms, he chose to spend the night at the gate with the guards. The guards must have been delighted to see Uriah and receive updates about their friends at the battlefront.

David was frustrated that his plan to conceal his sin did not work. He feigned concern for Uriah the next morning by asking why he did not return home to rest more comfortably since he had travelled a long way back to Jerusalem from the front.

Uriah explained he could not seek personal comfort knowing that the Ark was still in the tents, and his master Joab and his compatriots were still camping in the fields. His answer could have pricked David's heart in rebuke to him for personal indulgence and pleasure even by sleeping with Uriah's wife. David could have repented and turned from evil at that stage. But David's heart was already hardened as his sole purpose was to hide his sin from his people.

Be mindful of our thoughts and actions. Once we commit a sin and refuse to admit, repent and stop, we will continue to backslide and sink deeper into the mud. We are to flee temptation, not flirt with it. We are not even to tangle or test ourselves with it because Satan is powerful and deceptive. Pray therefore for God to help us stay away from places, people and circumstances that may tempt us.
11 MAY.part7: Watch me, O Lord. Guard my heart and mind. Help me to flee from temptation and protect me against all evil. Amen.

12 MAY.part4: And when David had called him, he did eat and drink before him; and he made him drunk: and at even he went out to lie on his bed with the servants of his lord, but went not down to his house.
12 MAY.part5:
David's first attempt of covering his sin with Bathsheba did not work as Uriah refused to sleep with his wife. Instead of being positively influenced by Uriah's solidarity with his men and his devotion to the Lord's Ark, David hatched a second plan. He would drink with Uriah and get him drunk, thinking that Uriah would then return home and intoxicated, not even remember whether or not he had lain with his wife. But again, Uriah refused to go home.

Uriah was devoted to God and king, as evidenced by his soldier's discipline and concern about the Ark. He treated his military duty as service to the Lord. It could be that he was resolved to be in a state of ritual purity which included refraining from sexual contact. David's second attempt failed and he was distressed. He was losing control of the situation to influence the outcome because Uriah was resolute and unwavering.

David's incident tells us that everyone can succumb to sin. In today's world, we are surrounded by many sin-inducing pressures and people with different value systems. As Christians, we need to be vigilant and remove ourselves from any tempting situation. As Paul advised Timothy, "Flee also youthful lusts: but follow righteousness, faith, charity, peace, with them that call on the Lord out of a pure heart" [2 Timothy 2:22]. Commit ourselves on a daily basis to the Lord to obey Him and ask Him to guard our hearts. God is faithful and He will not let us be tempted beyond what we can bear [1 Corinthians 10:13].
12 MAY.part7: "Wherewithal shall a young man cleanse his way? By taking heed thereto according to Thy word. With my whole heart have I sought Thee: O let me not wander from Thy commandments. Thy word have I hid in mine heart, that I might not sin against Thee." Read Psalm 119.

13 MAY.part4: And he wrote in the letter, saying, Set ye Uriah in the forefront of the hottest battle, and retire ye from him, that he may be smitten, and die.
13 MAY.part5:
David's scheme of getting Uriah to spend a night with Bathsheba failed twice. However, he refused to repent and turn to the Lord. Instead, he now devised an insidious plot, a deadly one. He signed Uriah's death warrant with the royal seal. David wrote a letter to Joab directing him to put Uriah in the front line of the fiercest battle. Then, the force would withdraw and abandon Uriah to the enemy. Joab would sacrifice a few good men together with Uriah. This scheme was so evilly plotted by David. Now David added murder to adultery. First, he coveted and seduced Uriah's wife, now he would take Uriah's and other innocent soldiers' lives. We can feel the added cruelty of this act in David sending the letter by the unwitting victim's own hand. It is unbelievable to see how such a commended servant of the Lord could fall so far and commit such deadly sins.

David did not resort to the Lord to deal with and resolve his messy situation. He had satisfied his lusts, now he went his own way to save his own reputation with his people. He thought once Uriah was killed, he would marry Bathsheba and close the sordid chapter.

This serves a serious warning to us to keep close to the Lord, meditate on His Word day and night and pray unceasingly. We see how fleshly lusts led David to stray, sin against God, harden his heart, and deprive himself of all sense of decency. Proverbs 6:32 says "But whoso committeth adultery with a woman lacketh understanding: he that doeth it destroyeth his own soul."
13 MAY.part7: Pray for the Lord to fill us with opportunities to grow in Him spiritually, serve Him and be productive. As we are weak in the flesh, pray for God's strength and wisdom to help us combat the temptations we will face.

14 MAY.part4: And the men of the city went out, and fought with Joab: and there fell some of the people of the servants of David; and Uriah the Hittite died also.
14 MAY.part5:
Joab did exactly what David commanded. He followed the king's orders, and Uriah was killed. Though this happened in a raging battle, Uriah was murdered just as surely as if David had wielded the knife himself. David murdered one of his best soldiers to cover his despicable sin. And sin if not immediately confronted, will take its wretched course. When the consequences of adultery threatened to expose his deed, David covered it first with deception and then with murder. Satan could never tempt David with the entire package all at once, but the devil lured and deceived him bit by bit, one step at a time.

The account of David and Bathsheba is so well known it is easy for us to treat it casually. We pass over the story quickly because it seems we know everything about it. But the clear line that separates righteousness from sinfulness must never be blurred, and neither should we cursorily pass over the account of this sordid affair.

God does not mask the sins of the saints; or disguise the wickedness of His people; rather, God exposes us so that we are compelled to admit that we are redeemed and saved by grace. It provides opportunity to warn us against being presumptuous - "Now all these things happened unto them for examples: and they are written for our admonition, upon whom the ends of the world are come" [1 Corinthians 10:11]. If we fail to learn from the failures of others, then we shall surely fall to the same sins and suffer its consequences, just as others also suffered.
14 MAY.part7: God will not permit His people to sin with impunity.

15 MAY.part4: Then Joab sent and told David all the things concerning the war;
15 MAY.part5:
Mission accomplished: Uriah was dead. Joab would send word to David, in a way that did not completely disclose the conspiracy; and did not make himself look like a murderer. Joab assumed David might possibly be angry at what had happened, the sacrifice of a number of his best soldiers through imprudently approaching too near the enemy's wall. He therefore figured that closing with the news of Uriah's death would settle David's anger and mitigate his displeasure over the deaths of the others. The effects of sin are rarely limited to just one person alone; they almost always involve the innocent who become its casualties. "Thy servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also", might be interpreted as meaning that it was without, or even in opposition to Joab's command, that Uriah went too far with his men, and that he was therefore chargeable for his own death. But Joab is as guilty as David in causing Uriah's death.

We should never allow ourselves to fall into a position where we are aiding and abetting someone's sin against God. Just as sin will be found out as Numbers 32:23 tells us, the one who defends a sin or helps in covering it up will one day stand in account for their bearing a false witness.

Be not partaker in someone else's sin for that only brings judgement upon yourself. As the saying goes: "Sin will take you further than you want to go, keep you longer than you want to stay and charge you more than you're willing to pay." You may well think the sin you have covered up is something you can manage but that's what David thought too.
15 MAY.part7: Those who attempt to cover up their sins, place others in danger.

16 MAY.part4: And the shooters shot from off the wall upon thy servants; and some of the king's servants be dead, and thy servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.
16 MAY.part5:
Why did the messenger not wait for David to respond in anger as Joab had instructed? Why did he inform David that Uriah was killed, before the king even uttered a word in criticism or protest? Perhaps he knew David wanted to get rid of Uriah, and that Joab had accomplished this by the excuse of an offensive against the enemy. If David knew Uriah had been killed, he would not raise any objections to the needless slaughter. Rather than waiting to see if the king would become angry about the stupidity of such a move, the messenger gave David the "good" news with the bad.

Throughout history, many attempts have been made to cover up incompetence, immorality, and crimes. Human attempts to cover up disobedience are futile. We all face decisions that make us wonder how important it is to stick to what is right rather than do what is easiest, least costly, least demanding, and most convenient at that moment. At times, doing what is expedient may be prudent, productive and perhaps the sensible thing. But when expediency displaces principled action and righteousness, we must re-examine our motives.

Do you find yourself excusing sins which you consider to be trivial? The saying goes that "small holes sink big ships". If for expedience we ignore significant changes that are happening gradually, we will eventually suffer the worse for it. Expedient behaviour leads to undesirable results and negative consequences. Take time to ask God to examine your heart, and confess even your little sins to Him.
16 MAY.part7: All things are lawful for me, but all things are not expedient: all things are lawful for me, but all things edify not - 1 Corinthians 10:23

17 MAY.part4: Then David said unto the messenger, Thus shalt thou say unto Joab, Let not this thing displease thee, for the sword devoureth one as well as another: make thy battle more strong against the city, and overthrow it: and encourage thou him.
17 MAY.part5:
David received the report with a secret satisfaction. Once he learnt that Uriah was dead, instead of being concerned with reckless tactics and dead Israelites, he simply overlooked and minimised the losses, with indifference to those who had died.

He was so relieved to hear of Uriah's death that he did not even care other lives were wasted in the process. This is the deadly effect of sin. It causes a person to become insensitive to what is right, so long as one's wanton craving had been satisfied. David had been hardened by the deceitfulness of sin. It tells us how unhinged David had become at this point. He had totally forgotten who he was. God was certainly very far from his mind.

When our hearts are callous to God, it makes it difficult to discern His voice and leading. Instead of steering clear of sin, we now tolerate and flirt with it. We casually allow it to coexist with godliness in our lives. Much of Christianity today does not reflect a healthy fear of God. It no longer influences the way many believers live. Have we become so inured to the presence of sin in this world that we are callous to it?

There is a giant lurking in our heart, and his desire is our demise. How are you dealing with this giant that is trying to destroy you? It is not the giant of sickness, suffering, sorrow, poverty, or pain. It is the giant of the old sinful self we carry around with us everyday that we need to fear most. Is our heart cold? Get it warm. Keep the fire for our Lord Jesus Christ burning in us.
17 MAY.part7: The problem we face in our Christian lives, is not that we don't have the Word of God; it is that we have become calloused to it.

18 MAY.part4: And when the mourning was past, David sent and fetched her to his house, and she became his wife, and bare him a son. But the thing that David had done displeased the LORD.
18 MAY.part5:
The death of Bathsheba's husband, Uriah, is one of the most regrettable events recorded, given his unreserved and unquestionable loyalty to his king, who duplicitously schemed and plotted his death because of the adultery with his wife. Though David would be forgiven, this heinous sin remained a stigma throughout his entire life [1 Kings 15:5]. While Bathsheba mourned her husband's death, inwardly she may have struggled with the guilt of her unconfessed adultery. Was there deep remorse in her heart? Or relief ? "Captain Uriah husband is now dead, king David husband-to-be just ahead!"

As soon as the days of mourning, which probably lasted seven days, were accomplished, David took her to be his wife. While her situation now to remarry was legitimate (her spouse being dead), yet this was a rushed marriage to cover up her unlawful pregnancy which would eventually bear them a son. On the surface, it seems to have worked out, but the thing that David did displeased the LORD. What a stinging thought! Men look on the outward appearance, but the LORD looks at the heart.

Scripture is a true and faithful witness. It will not connive with but will expose even the sins of the most celebrated saints. They are recorded, not for their humiliation nor our emulation but for our admonition, to the intent that he who thinks he is strong to withstand temptation must take heed lest he falls! As for the guilt-smitten ones, the panacea is to look to the Lord, for He is good, "and ready to forgive; and plenteous in mercy unto all them that call upon Thee" [Psalm 86:5].
18 MAY.part7: How sad our state by nature is, our sin how deep it stains; And Satan binds our captive minds fast in his slavish chains. But there's a voice of sov'reign grace sounds from the sacred Word, "Ho! ye despairing sinners come, and trust upon the Lord." (Isaac Watts)

19 MAY.part4: And the LORD sent Nathan unto David. And he came unto him, and said unto him, There were two men in one city; the one rich, and the other poor.
19 MAY.part5:
The holy and gracious Lord will not allow His beloved ones to continue in unconfessed sin. He sent the prophet Nathan to David with a parable. The parable was plain and evident. Its intent was to lead David to pronounce judgement upon himself, and realise the gravity of the evil committed, not only against his loyal servant, but also against his holy God.

The parable relates how a rich and powerful man oppressed a feeble and poor man. The rich man, unthinkably selfish (despite his wealth), pitiless and unreasonable, took away the poor man's only lamb to feed his guest. Hearing this account, David's anger was so greatly kindled that he declared the perpetrator unworthy of living in God's eyes and pronounced his victim to be restored fourfold.

Why did God send the prophet to confront David with a parable? Perhaps his kingly status and authority would make him defensive or even imperil Nathan's life in accusing and offending the king [1 Kings 13:4; 2 Chronicles 26:16-19]. A parable would cause David to look away from himself and deliver fair judgement.

Christ in His earthly ministry frequently used parables when speaking to the multitudes about the kingdom of God, in order to discern the true seekers from the false, who "seeing see not; and hearing they hear not, neither do they understand" [Matthew 13:13]. Pray to God that our eyes may be opened to see, and our ears receptive to hear the truth of the heavenly kingdom, for often, the natural man is dull of hearing because the things of God are spiritually discerned [1 Corinthian 2:14].
19 MAY.part7: Earthly representations adroitly told, heavenly realities fascinatingly unfold.

20 MAY.part3: VERSE 6 neighbout's cattle, he shall be restored fourfold
20 MAY.part4: And he shall restore the lamb fourfold, because he did this thing, and because he had no pity.
20 MAY.part5:
Agodly and righteous king till this point, David was familiar with the Mosaic law. God's Word directed that the king should keep a copy of it "and it shall be with him, and he shall read therein all the days of his life: that he may learn to fear the LORD his God, to keep all the words of this law and these statutes, to do them" [Deuteronomy 17:18-20].

The Mosaic law mandated that if a man was found guilty of stealing, killing or selling his neighbour's cattle, he shall be restored fourfold or fivefold, according to their value [Exodus 22:1]. David meted out a fourfold restoration judgement on the perpetrator, not realising he was pronouncing judgement on himself. He was guilty of stealing someone's wife, killing her husband and showing no pity. Fourfold restitution was to be made.

Zacchaeus, a chief publican and tax collector, reviled by his own people as a great sinner for cheating them in his trade, would meet the Lord Jesus and be convicted of his sins. In repentance, he declared, "Lord; Behold, Lord, the half of my goods I give to the poor; and if I have taken any thing from any man by false accusation, I restore him fourfold" [Luke 19:8].

This is true Scriptural repentance. Regret or sorrow without repentance, will never find favour with God. True repentance is more than just making a declaration. It is a decision driven by a change of heart, accompanied by forsaking the sin, satisfied by rightful restitution and manifested wholly in a new life perspective which is God- centered, delighting in His Word and doing what He commands.
20 MAY.part7: Sin forsaken is one of the best evidences of sin forgiven. - JC Ryle

21 MAY.part3: VERSE 7 confronted with his offence, to seek a scapegoat to
21 MAY.part4: And Nathan said to David, Thou art the man. Thus saith the LORD God of Israel, I anointed thee king over Israel, and I delivered thee out of the hand of Saul.
21 MAY.part5:
Upon reacting to and pronouncing judgement on the rich man in the parable, Nathan's reply came as a thunderbolt to awaken David and convict him of his evil deeds - thou art the man! Suddenly, things took a drastic turn, and it became plainly clear to him. He was the guilty man with nowhere to hide. His sin had found him out. He had to face it and deal with it.

It is a natural tendency for a man when confronted with his offence, to seek a scapegoat to blame or minimise his actions by casting himself as a victim of unfortunate circumstances. Like Adam, who "blamed" God for giving him Eve, who caused his downfall. So swift at pointing to others, but slow to blame oneself!

How true and how contradicting that while before the all-seeing God, we confess our sinful failures, manifold human weaknesses, and woeful imperfections; when confronted with our own faults and offences by our fellowmen, we react with swift and angry defensiveness. Indeed, a paradox that we are broken and contrite before God but self-righteous and proud before men. This is pharisaical hypocrisy!

During the Passover feast, the Lord said to His disciples, " ... one of you shall betray Me." The response of His sorrowful disciples was, "Lord, Is it I?" [Matthew 26:20-22], not "who, who is it?". While the Adamic nature is still an integral part of us, the truly sanctified and humble man will be swift to self-examine, and slow to blame others when confronted by his wrongdoings.
21 MAY.part7: It is easier to cry against one-thousand sins of others than to kill one of your own. - John Flavel

22 MAY.part4: And I gave thee thy master's house, and thy master's wives into thy bosom, and gave thee the house of Israel and of Judah; and if that had been too little, I would moreover have given unto thee such and such things.
22 MAY.part5:
After David was jolted out of spiritual callousness, Nathan began his prophetic announcement with "Thus saith the LORD God of Israel". The last time such an announcement was made, God had reminded David of His steadfast love and grace towards him and promised an eternal throne and kingdom to his descendants [2 Samuel 7:5-17].

This time round, circumstances were starkly different. David had committed some of the most heinous sins. Still God confronted him by reminding David of His covenantal faithfulness and generous provision. Be it power, protection, or possessions, God had graciously provided for David in abundance. But David had forgotten all these and chose to lust after and unscrupulously obtain what he had not been given. It is in the context of such abundant covenantal blessings that makes David's transgressions all the more treacherous and vile.

Indeed, it is easy to forget God's grace towards us, especially when times are good, and everything is going smoothly. Even for those who may not have much materially, let us not forget that God's richest blessing is not in temporal things but in the eternal Lord Jesus. Through our Lord, we have forgiveness of sins, peace with God, the sure hope of eternal life, and all spiritual blessings besides.

Let us cultivate this spirit of gratitude and thanksgiving, for when we lose sight of the Giver, we will stop relying on Him to provide us our needs and instead sin to satisfy our wants.
22 MAY.part7: Bless the Lord, O my soul, and forget not all His benefits: Who forgiveth all thine iniquities; Who healeth all thy diseases; Who redeemeth thy life from destruction; Who crowneth thee with lovingkindness and tender mercies; Who satisfieth thy mouth with good things; so that thy youth is renewed like the eagle's. - Psalm 103:2-5

23 MAY.part4: Wherefore hast thou despised the commandment of the LORD, to do evil in His sight? thou hast killed Uriah the Hittite with the sword, and hast taken his wife to be thy wife, and hast slain him with the sword of the children of Ammon.
23 MAY.part5:
After exposing the callousness of David's heart, Nathan set David's iniquities before him. First and foremost, David had "despised the commandment of the Lord". To despise a thing is to show contempt for it or take it lightly. The opposite is to treat it with honour and reverence.

How does one despise the commandments of the LORD? Numbers 15:30-31 tell us that we despise God's word when we wilfully break them - not so much because we hate them, but because we do not care enough about them to keep them. They are insignificant or of little value to us. When we despise the commandments, we are despising God Himself, for we do not esteem Him enough to give weight to His Word.

It is inconceivable that David, lauded as a man after God's own heart, whom God had so richly blessed, would despise God and His word. But he did. Consumed by lust, he abused his power and broke God's laws to get what he wanted. Satisfying his lusts took priority over obedience to God.

Have we also despised the Lord's commandment? Our sins may not seem as grievous as David's. We may not think much of our 'little' sins because they seem harmless. But when we wilfully continue in these sins, we are despising God and His commandments. We ignore how offensive every sin is to our holy God. We minimise the fact that our Lord Jesus had to suffer and die to atone for even every "little" sin of ours.
23 MAY.part7: Whoso despiseth the Word shall be destroyed: but he that feareth the commandment shall be rewarded. - Proverbs 13:13

24 MAY.part4: Now therefore the sword shall never depart from thine house; because thou hast despised me, and hast taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be thy wife.
24 MAY.part5:
Next, Nathan prophesied David's future troubles. Because David had caused Uriah to die a violent death, his household would be plagued with violence for the rest of his life. This was fulfilled when internal strife and hatred led to the violent deaths of his sons, Amnon, Absalom, and Adonijah. Not only that, because David took another man's wife, his own wives would be openly violated, thus bringing shame and dishonour upon him and his family.

This episode reminds us that God hates sin; He will never let sin go unpunished. Some Christians think that as long as we confess our sins, we would be forgiven, and everything would be "reset" to normal. As God has promised, He would forgive us our sins as long as we truly repent and confess them [1 John 1:9]. However, when God forgives, it does not mean He simply dismisses or overlooks sin. A holy and just God must punish sin, but the punishment was borne by His Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, on the cross on our behalf.

Then, even though our sins are forgiven, there will still be its consequences. We should not confuse consequences with punishment, lest we think we are paying the debt of sin because we suffer the negative consequences of our actions. For Christians, even when we suffer consequences for our own sins, we can endure because we know that behind every chastening is our heavenly Father, who lovingly disciplines His children to bring them back to the path of righteousness.
24 MAY.part7: Now no chastening for the present seemeth to be joyous, but grievous: nevertheless afterward it yieldeth the peaceable fruit of righteousness unto them which are exercised thereby. - Hebrews 12:11

25 MAY.part4: And David said unto Nathan, I have sinned against the LORD. And Nathan said unto David, The LORD also hath put away thy sin; thou shalt not die.
25 MAY.part5:
In response to Nathan's charge, David admitted he had sinned against the LORD. Immediately after he uttered these words, Nathan declared that the Lord had heard and forgiven, and David would not die.

David did not try to defend himself or say more. Yet he was readily forgiven. On the surface, it seems like a simple acknowledgement that one has sinned is all that is necessary to receive forgiveness. However, it is interesting to note the phrase "I have sinned", which is but one word in Hebrew, has also been used by many others in the Bible - Pharaoh, Balaam, Achan, Saul, and others - to a different outcome. This is because few truly understood that word or meant what they said.

Fundamentally, sin is not so much about doing wrong to others; it is rebellion against God, an assault on His authority. This is why when Nathan confronted David, his primary charge against David was, "Wherefore hast thou despised the commandment of the Lord?" No doubt what David did to Uriah and Bathsheba was absolutely wrong, his sin was still essentially against God Himself.

True repentance begins with recognising how serious and offensive every sin is to our holy God. Until we understand this, the words "I have sinned" will merely be an expression of regret, be it due to the consequences to oneself or to others. If we truly comprehend the seriousness of sin, then we will not only turn away from sin, but also turn to God and seek to restore our broken relationship with Him.
25 MAY.part7: Do you take sin seriously? Do you take Christ seriously? If not, pray and ask God to convict you of your sins, so that you may rediscover the glory of Christ's salvation.

26 MAY.part4: And Saul said unto Samuel, I have sinned: for I have transgressed the commandment of the LORD, and thy words: because I feared the people, and obeyed their voice.
26 MAY.part5:
David admitted he had sinned against the LORD when Nathan confronted him. Saul had made a similar confession to Samuel. Both recognised they had sinned against God. However, the results of their confession were different for David and Saul - David was forgiven but Saul was rejected. Why? What constitutes true repentance?

Let us study Saul's response. There were many signs that indicate his repentance was not genuine. First, he was not convicted of his sin. Saul was insistent he had obeyed God's commandment, even in the face of incriminating evidence. Apparently, he did not fully comprehend the seriousness of his offence against God. He was not appalled by what he had done.

Next, he cared about his own honour and authority, not God's. Even after learning that God had rejected him, Saul was more concerned that Samuel should appear with him before the people so that he might continue to have the appearance of divine approval and authority.

Lastly, Saul did not accept sin's consequences. He tried to justify himself by giving excuses. Although he confessed, his actions showed his confession did not come from true repentance, but a desire to reverse the sentence and avoid the consequences of sin. He was sorry, not for his transgressions but for being found out.

True repentance has no room for self- justification, or self-preservation, or self-pity. It is not directed towards self but towards God. If you are wondering whether you have truly repented, ask God to grant it to you. Ultimately, true repentance is the work of the Holy Spirit, a gift that only God can give.
26 MAY.part7: In meekness instructing those that oppose themselves; if God peradventure will give them repentance to the acknowledging of the truth. - 2 Timothy 2:25

27 MAY.part4: Against Thee, Thee only, have I sinned, and done this evil in Thy sight: that Thou mightest be justified when Thou speakest, and be clear when thou judgest.
27 MAY.part5:
Through prophet Nathan's denouncement, David's crime had been exposed and he was left with a crushing weight of guilt resulting in him writing this psalm. David dared not hide behind any excuses to justify his actions, nor did he cite any past merits and achievements to plead for leniency. He simply prostrated himself before His judge and appealed to God's character, His lovingkindness and tender mercies, and begged for mercy and forgiveness.

David accepted full responsibility for his sin. Note the numerous personal pronouns he used: my sin, my transgressions, my iniquity, I have sinned, I have done this evil. He also used three different words to describe his wrongdoing. As one who knew God's laws and character, he knew that through his sin, transgression, and iniquity, he had wilfully rebelled against his God, wickedly violated His laws and fallen far short of His standards. By his actions, he had "given great occasion to the enemies of the Lord to blaspheme" [2 Samuel 12:14].

David's prayer is more than a personal cry to God. It is a model of true repentance and holds powerful lessons for us. Even though we have not committed murder and adultery, we have all broken God's commandments in deed and thought, and have all sinned and fallen short of His glory. But because of the finished work of the Lord Jesus Christ on Calvary's cross, God will blot out our transgressions, wash us of our iniquity and cleanse us of our sin.
27 MAY.part7: Then Peter said unto them, Repent, and be baptized every one of you in the name of Jesus Christ for the remission of sins, and ye shall receive the gift of the Holy Ghost. - Acts 2:38

28 MAY.part4: Purge me with hyssop, and I shall be clean: wash me, and I shall be whiter than snow.
28 MAY.part5:
David did not simply stop at confessing his sin and asking for forgiveness as we often do. He understood the depth of his sin, that it went beyond specific sinful actions all the way to a stubborn sin nature, one he was born with. As such, he asked God to change him on the inside, his "hidden part"; something that none of us can do ourselves, not even David was able to do himself. Only the God who created us, and who knows our hearts can do that.

David asked God to purge (cleanse) him with hyssop. Hyssop was used to apply the blood of the Passover lamb [Exodus 12:22]. Hyssop was also used to sprinkle the priest's purifying water [Numbers 19:18]. He desired God to cleanse him through the blood of the perfect sacrifice anticipated by the animal sacrifices of the Old Testament. His hope was that his heavy burden of sin and guilt would be lifted and he would once again be able to experience joy and gladness. In verse 9, he again asked God to forgive him.

And this is what God desires to do, not only for His dear servant David, but for all who fear Him. He is our Heavenly Father. He knows our frame and remembers that we are dust. As far as the east is from the west, so far will He remove our transgressions from us [Psalm 103:11-14]. But the Righteous God can only do so when we come by faith to the Cross and let our Lord Jesus Christ take on the punishment that we deserve.
28 MAY.part7: But He was wounded for our transgressions, He was bruised for our iniquities: the chastisement of our peace was upon Him; and with His stripes we are healed. - Isaiah 53:5

29 MAY.part4: Restore unto me the joy of Thy salvation; and uphold me with Thy free spirit.
29 MAY.part5:
David wanted more than a cleaned-up heart. He pleaded for God to create in him a new heart. Again, this is something only God can do. In Ezekiel 36:26, God promised His people that, under the New Covenant, He would take away their stony heart and give them a new heart and put a new spirit within them. To keep his new heart pure, David prayed for a "right (or steadfast) spirit" [v.10], God's "holy spirit" [v. 11], and a "free (or generous) spirit" [v. 12]. He was fearful that God's spirit might depart from him as he did from Saul [1 Samuel 16:14] and Samson [Judges 16:20]. He wanted to walk close to God and experience again the joy of the Lord which he dearly missed during those months of unconfessed sin and spiritual defeat.

Joy is the result of God's work in people. Even as God's displeasure with sin brings judgement, so His pleasure brings joy of heart [v. 8, 12], This joy is more than an emotion. It is a contented resting in God; a blessed assurance of having been reconciled with the Lord and having peace with Him [Romans 5:1]. This is "the joy of salvation".

David promised he would tell all who have committed sin that God forgives. He would pass on this knowledge to others that they might also be saved. All of us who name the name of our Lord Jesus Christ too can do this. In fact, it is the great commission of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ.
29 MAY.part7: "Well done, thou good and faithful servant ... enter thou into the joy of thy lord" [Matthew 25:21, 23]. When the Lord returns, will you hear these words from Him?

30 MAY.part4: Deliver me from bloodguiltiness, O God, Thou God of my salvation: and my tongue shall sing aloud of Thy righteousness.
30 MAY.part5:
Praise is the natural response to divine deliverance. The person who has tasted the grace of God in his life cannot but love Him and praise Him. During His encounter with the woman of sin in the home of Simon the Pharisee [Luke 7:36-48], the Lord remarked that those who have been forgiven much love much. David certainly had been forgiven much because his sin was especially vile, involving lust, treachery and shedding of innocent blood of one who was brave and loyal to him. Hence David resolved to praise God and sing aloud His righteousness. He wanted all that was within him to bless God's holy Name [Psalm 103:1]. Consequently, he penned numerous beautiful psalms of praise which have become a source of encouragement to millions of believers through the ages.

There are two important lessons that we can learn from today's reading. Firstly, we must recognise our sins and come before God with a broken heart and a contrite spirit. We cannot approach Him on our own merits and achievements. We can only approach Him on the merits of the great sacrifice that our Lord Jesus made for us at the Cross.

Secondly, let us praise Him with grateful hearts all the days of our lives. Let us present our bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is our reasonable service [Romans 12:1]. Let us go into this lost world and "preach the Gospel of peace, and bring glad tidings of good things" [Romans 10:15] to all who need to hear it.
30 MAY.part7: Jesus Christ can deliver us from the power of sin as well as from the guilt of sin. - Martyn Lloyd Jones, Walking with God Day by Day

31 MAY.part3: VERSE 18 [Joshua 7], what more that of a king.
31 MAY.part4: Do good in thy good pleasure unto Zion: build thou the walls of Jerusalem.
31 MAY.part5:
By the end of his prayer, David was confident that his relationship with God had been restored. Hence, he ended his psalm with an intercession for the nation. David was fearful his sin might have repercussions for Israel. When Achan sinned in the days of Israel's conquest of Canaan, the army of Israel could not conquer the tiny town of Ai until Achan's sin was judged. If the sin of a citizen like Achan could destroy the nation's effectiveness [Joshua 7], what more that of a king.

Some Bible teachers believe verses 18 and 19 were added to Psalm 51 during the Babylonian exile because at that time, David was still in the process of repairing and building the city's walls; and the temple would only be built during the reign of his son, Solomon. There is no compelling reason for this hypothesis. It is likely that David was moving from prayer for himself to prayer for the people committed to him, something he did in other psalms such as Psalms 5, 25, 28 and 40. He prayed that God will do good to Zion and build the walls of Jerusalem. At that time, God would be pleased to receive the public sacrifices offered willingly by grateful hearts.

Christians should also pray like David. If we truly repent of our sins, God is "faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness" [1 John 1:9]. We should also pray for our families, our church, and our nation.
31 MAY.part7: Words may be wanting, but prayer will ascend; for prayer is rather the language of heart than lip. - James Smith, Daily Remembrancer

1 JUNE.part4: And Nathan said unto David, The LORD also hath put away thy sin; thou shalt not die. Howbeit, because by this deed thou hast given great occasion to the enemies of the LORD to blaspheme, the child also that is born unto thee shall surely die.
1 JUNE.part5:
David lusted after Bathsheba, a married woman, planned the murder of Uriah her husband, and despised the commandments of the LORD. He was guilty on at least three counts, namely adultery ("Thou shalt not commit adultery."); murder ("Thou shalt not kill."); and covetousness ("Thou shalt not covet.").

He feigned ignorance for a year until he was woken up from his self-deception by God's prophet Nathan. He made no excuse for his sin and did not attempt to conceal his guilt any longer. In deepest contrition of heart, he instantly confessed and repented, "I have sinned against the LORD." To which Nathan replied, "The LORD also hath put away thy sin; thou shalt not die" [v. 13b]. The legal penalty for adultery was death [Leviticus 20:10]. The full expression of David's confession can be studied in Psalm 51, which could be considered an important commentary for verse 13.

Nevertheless, Nathan also said "the child also that is born unto thee shall surely die" [v. 14b], to vindicate God's reputation for righteousness among the nations and to stop the mouths of the blasphemers [v. 14a]. Although God forgives sins, He does not wipe out the inescapable and painful consequences. David took Uriah's life and for this, he would lose four of his sons. The son conceived in sin with Bathsheba would die of sickness [2 Samuel 12:14, 18], and three of his oldest sons would meet violent deaths [2 Samuel 12:10]: Amnon [2 Samuel 13:28-29], Absalom [2 Samuel 18:14-15] and Adonijah [1 Kings 2:25].

By God's grace, David went through every of these consequences and endured them given the promise of God. Although God's forgiveness is boundless and accessible, we ought not to presume upon it. Sin is not something to be treated lightly.
1 JUNE.part7: Repentant and forgiven sinners, always be sorry for sin and watchful against it.

2 JUNE.part4: David therefore besought God for the child; and David fasted, and went in, and lay all night upon the earth.
2 JUNE.part5:
The LORD struck the child whom Bathsheba bore for David with a terminal sickness. Though prophet Nathan had said that the child, the fruit of David's sinful union with Bathsheba, would surely die, David still pleaded with God to spare that life.

Why did David pray so hard, having been told the child would die? He was praying for God's grace. He gave this answer: "Who can tell whether GOD will be gracious to me, that the child may live?" [2 Samuel 12:22]. The LORD had forgiven and restored him, and David thought He might also grant his plea for mercy to let the child live.

David prayed as earnestly as any man could pray, but God's clear answer was "No", and David was content with that. He accepted God's will and continued to worship Him in spite of the loss and pain. Sometimes we too must accept "No" from God as the answer to our pleas. Like David, we should accept His will and continue to worship Him and faithfully serve Him. How many of us praise God when he has said "No"? Life goes on. Look ahead and look upwards. Do not look behind and dwell in the past.

God had shown grace to David and Bathsheba far beyond what they could have hoped for or deserved. Bathsheba would conceive again and bear a second son who would bear a double name - Solomon, meaning "peaceful" and the LORD through Nathan named him Jedidah, which meant "beloved of the LORD." The LORD loved the child, signifying His continued blessing upon David. Solomon was the chosen one to succeed David as Israel's next king. Even in His discipline, the LORD is gracious to His own. In wrath, He remembers mercy.
2 JUNE.part7: I, even I, am He that blotteth out thy transgressions for Mine own sake, and will not remember thy sins. - Isaiah 43:25

3 JUNE.part4: But when David saw that his servants whispered, David perceived that the child was dead: therefore David said unto his servants, Is the child dead? And they said, He is dead.
3 JUNE.part5:
The prophet confronted David regarding his heinous sin with Bathsheba and pronounced a judgement against him. Even though the LORD had graciously forgiven David, judgement came in the form of the death of the infant child [v. 14]. The newborn became seriously ill, and despite David's intense fasting, prayer and sincere petitions, died. God's chastisement stood. An innocent child died instead of the guilty pair. This infant, a member of David's family, would be the first to suffer the deadly wages of sin. The child did not die as punishment for his own sin; it was a disciplinary consequence of David's transgression.

The Greek word translated "wage" is opsonion. "Wage" is the word for salary or payment given to someone for his work and services rendered. Thus, the wages of sin refer to the reward which comes as a result of serving Satan. How does the Bible define sin? 1 John 3:4 says, "Whosoever committeth sin transgresseth also the law: for sin is the transgression of the law." The answer to Question 14 of the Westminster Shorter Catechism tells us, "Sin is any want of conformity unto, or transgression of the law of God."

David had sinned against God, but he was not punished with death. Adultery and murder, both were sufficient cause for execution, even for a king. The genuine and contrite repentance which he expressed both to Nathan and fully to the LORD in Psalm 51 was more than sufficient to forgive and restore him. However, the impact of his sin remained and continued to work its sorrow in Israel, in his family and his life. Sin is sin and must be hated and shunned, for its wages is death [Romans 6:23].
3 JUNE.part7: I have sinned against Thee, LORD. Please forgive me.

4 JUNE.part4: Then David arose from the earth, and washed, and anointed himself, and changed his apparel, and came into the house of the LORD, and worshipped: then he came to his own house; and when he required, they set bread before him, and he did eat.
4 JUNE.part5:
In times of great sadness and grief, it is not surprising if life seems to come to a standstill. When a loved one passes away, it may feel almost sacrilegious to be carrying on our business as usual. Perhaps we may be conveying the impression that the loss of the loved one was of little consequence. In this passage however, David sets us an example of how we ought to move on. Before his son's death, David fasted and besought God for mercy on behalf of the child. But when it became clear it was God's will that the child should die, David submitted himself to divine will, picked himself up and moved on with the matter of living.

Let us also note David did not just tend to his physical needs. After washing himself and changing his clothes, he made sure God was worshipped before satisfying his physical hunger. His spiritual duties took precedence over his physical needs. This is an important principle in our Christian walk. Our Lord Jesus exhorts us to "seek ye first the kingdom of God, and His righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you" [Matthew 6:33].

After a tragic event in life, one of our most important need is to ensure our relationship with God is intact and not adversely affected. We may be tempted to feel bitterness or blame God. That puts us in danger of sinful pride - as though we know better than God and are unwilling to submit to His higher will. In contrast, by worshipping Him, we acknowledge His sovereignty over our lives, and remind ourselves of His covenanted goodness towards us.
4 JUNE.part7: When sorrows like sea billows roll, whatever my lot, Thou hast taught me to say, "it is well, it is well with my soul". - Horatio G. Spafford

5 JUNE.part4: But now he is dead, wherefore should I fast? can I bring him back again? I shall go to him, but he shall not return to me.
5 JUNE.part5:
As we read yesterday, David's behaviour appeared strange to his servants. It is not common for people to be able to move on quickly after the death of a loved one.

Today, we examine David's explanation to his puzzled servants. We will focus on two aspects of David's answer. First, David demonstrated an understanding of God's graciousness and omniscience [v. 22]. While David's child yet lived, David fasted and wept to show the depth of his sorrow and repentance over his own sin of adultery. He knew God was merciful and gracious. In times past, God had pronounced judgement on Israel but then graciously withheld punishment because they repented. Furthermore, David also knew God does not look at outward appearances, but He examines one's heart. This meant God knew if David was truly repentant over his sin or just putting on an act to save his son.

Next, we see David demonstrating absolute faith in God's goodness [v. 23]. When his child died, David understood fully it was God's will for this to come to pass. Instead of becoming bitter or being unable to accept God's will, David bowed himself down in humble submission. He would trust that all things work together for good to them that love God [Romans 8:28], and he was able to testify to his faith - that despite his sin and the tragic consequences, David had confidence God had forgiven him and one day he would be reunited with his son in heaven.
5 JUNE.part7: God knows always and He knows best. Even before a great tragedy strikes, do we already have difficulty submitting to His will?

6 JUNE.part3: VERSE 23 6:47]. David was able to get over his grief because
6 JUNE.part4: But now he is dead, wherefore should I fast? can I bring him back again? I shall go to him, but he shall not return to me.
6 JUNE.part5:
Even among Christians, death tends to be a scary thing, and some may be tempted to call it a great unknown. Often, this fear stems from the notion that what happens when life ends is unclear and uncharted. Inherent in this fear is a lack of faith in and knowledge of God's Word. In the Bible, we have the clear, written promises from an omnipotent God that those who believe in Him will not perish but have everlasting life [John 3:16; 6:47]. David was able to get over his grief because he was confident that one day he would see his son again in heaven. He was confident there was life after death. It was not a great unknown. When we have faith in God's Word, we need not fear death for as the prophet has said, "He (the Lord) will swallow up death in victory" [Isaiah 25:8], and after Calvary, the apostle affirms it [1 Corinthians 15:54]. "For if we have been planted together in the likeness of his death, we shall be also in the likeness of his resurrection" [Romans 6:5].

Many may also be wondering why David was confident his son would go to heaven. The Westminster Confession of Faith states that "Elect infants, dying in infancy, are regenerated and saved by Christ through the Spirit, who worketh when, and where, and how He pleaseth ..." (WCF 10:3). Even though babies are born with original sin, the sovereign God in His great mercy and wisdom will deal with them with loving graciousness. This would be consistent with Luke 18:15-16 where Christ explicitly tells His disciples, "Suffer little children to come unto Me, and forbid them not: for of such is the kingdom of God."
6 JUNE.part7: Is my fear of death a measure of my faith in God?

7 JUNE.part4: And David comforted Bathsheba his wife, and went in unto her, and lay with her: and she bare a son, and he called his name Solomon: and the LORD loved him.
7 JUNE.part5:
David's adultery had led to the death of his son. Now that he had repented and made right with God, David was blessed with another son - Solomon. Solomon would go on to become the next king of Israel and a distant ancestor of our Lord Jesus Christ. It is specifically described for us that "the LORD loved him".

This is indeed great encouragement. Christians may have been disobedient to God in such a way that they are now trapped in situations where they would not have been in, if they had been obedient to God's Word. Yet, to extricate themselves is also no longer possible because it would be committing another sin and displeasing God even more. For example, a Christian may have sinned wilfully in marrying a non-believer. Once married however, to seek a divorce to get out of the unequal union would be a further sin.

David had truly repented of his adultery, and God chose no longer to remember that sin [Hebrews 8:12]. In His great mercy, God instead chose to love this child, and to use this child as an avenue to bring the promised Messiah into the world. Let us be encouraged that there is no sin too great for God to forgive. Even if you seem stuck in a situation you would not have gotten into if you had been fully obedient, there is still room at the cross for you.
7 JUNE.part7: Can I remove myself from my sinful situation without incurring greater sin?
