8 JUNE.part4: And Joab sent messengers to David, and said, I have fought against Rabbah, and have taken the city of waters. Now therefore gather the rest of the people together, and encamp against the city, and take it: lest I take the city, and it be called after my name.
8 JUNE.part5:
The account returns now to the battle against the Ammonites in Rabbah. This event took place after a two-year siege between David's fall into sin and his eventual repentance. It was also this very occasion that provided David with the opportunity to cover any traces of his grievous sin of adultery by being complicit in the death of Uriah [2 Samuel 11:1, 7, 15]. A short time after Uriah's death, in these verses, the Israelites have captured Rabbah's strongly defended area and cut off the city's water supply. They could now easily take the whole city, and Joab called David down from Jerusalem to have the honour of leading the triumphal entry. Also, the presence of a large army would completely subjugate the entire country after the capture of its capital.

On the cusp of seizing the city, it is interesting how 'Joab sent messengers to David' to give him the honour of entering it as the victor. This shows that despite Joab's infamy for his falsehoods, dubious and unworthy character, he had praiseworthy loyalty to David - even the worst of men have some good qualities, sometimes.

This account gives us a more important lesson: while David's army emerged victorious and the siege of Rabbah ended triumphantly, we find David overcome by temptation and fallen into grievous sin. He was troubled by a guilty conscience which would ultimately come to fore. Worldly success and prosperity are not true measure of moral worth, nor guarantee of inward peace and happiness. May the Lord remind us of this always.
8 JUNE.part7: Father in heaven, I pray that you may grant me a heart of chastity and holiness. It is my desire that my heart be right with Thee. In Jesus' name, Amen.

9 JUNE.part4: And he took their king's crown from off his head, the weight whereof was a talent of gold with the precious stones: and it was set on David's head. And he brought forth the spoil of the city in great abundance.
9 JUNE.part5:
Having taken Rabbah, David now put on the king's crown as a symbol of his subjection of the Ammonites to his rule [v. 30]. From a beginning of contempt and pride [2 Samuel 10:1-4], the city with its king and inhabitants now suffered a disastrous end. They trusted Moloch their false god in vain.

Sadly, the retribution did not end here, but it was marked by further violence and bloodshed - the people put under saws, harrows of iron, axes or iron, and made to pass through the brick-kiln [v. 31]. While these acts of violence and retaliation were brutal and inhumane, they must be seen in the context of the historical age in which they took place, not with reference to modern times. Evidently, the Ammonites were themselves a savage and brutal nation [1 Samuel 11:1-2; 2 Samuel 10:1- 4; Amos 1:13], and this likely was the way they were accustomed to treating their vanquished foes. We could say that they faced the just deserts.

"To execute vengeance upon the heathen, and punishments upon the people" [Psalm 149:7]. Indeed, David had been appointed here as the instrument of God's divine judgement. By the principle of lex talionis or the Law of Retaliation, the Ammonites justly deserved what they had meted out to others. On David's part however, we cannot defend these excessively severe atrocities David has committed. In the light of truth and righteousness, this perhaps may be a blot on David's renown as Israel's king.
9 JUNE.part7: Father in heaven, I thank You that You are our King. Unlike earthly dominions, You change not, and with You there is no variableness, neither shadow of turning. Watch over us in Your mighty sovereignty. In Jesus' name, Amen.

10 JUNE.part4: And it came to pass after this, that Absalom the son of David had a fair sister, whose name was Tamar; and Amnon the son of David loved her.
10 JUNE.part5:
"And it came to pass after this ..." shows that these tragic events were connected to God's judgement against David's house as prophesied by Nathan in Chapter 12 for his sin of adultery followed by the murder of Uriah. God's sovereignty in no way mitigates man's responsibility [James 1:13-15].

At this time, David would have been king over all Israel for more than a decade. He had reached the zenith of his glory, and his kingship was well-established. His wars and struggles were over - Rabbah was captured, and his empire firmly established. Hereafter, he would sit upon his throne for another twenty years. However, despite the glory and honour of kingship, he was a guilty culprit, and he must bear the many sorrows resulting from his sin.

The account here is wrought with intense carnality and repugnant disgust, a complicated plot with involvement of multiple members in David's extended household. Amnon was David's firstborn, the son of Ahinoam of Jezreel. It has been conjectured Amnon would not have committed his shameless crime had not David's own sin and poor example loosened the bonds of parental authority. Amnon hesitated at first but was encouraged by his cousin Jonadab [v. 3].

The chastisement of God which David experienced came chiefly through the repercussions on his family and of their actions. The misconduct of his sons can largely be attributed to David's own sins and disobedience against God. As God's redeemed, the way we live can either be used to testify for the glory of God or to bring reproach to His Name.
10 JUNE.part7: But if ye will not do so, behold, ye have sinned against the LORD: and be sure your sin will find you out. - Numbers 32:23

11 JUNE.part4: And it came to pass after this, that Absalom the son of David had a fair sister, whose name was Tamar; and Amnon the son of David loved her.
11 JUNE.part5:
As mentioned previously, the account in this chapter is intense, complicated and repugnant, with the chastisement of God which David experienced coming upon him chiefly through the complicated affairs within his family.

This chapter reveals the dark and filthy stain within David's family in its manifestations of sin - lust, anger, hatred, vengeance, selfish ambition, and rivalry. The characters involved were filled with deception and mired in intrigue. While David was such an admirable ruler of his kingdom, he had failed miserably as a ruler of his own household.

David's personal testimony may well be the cause of these family feuds. While he was a man after God's own heart [1 Samuel 13:14] with many good qualities, his sins of adultery and murder would have great impact and consequences for him and his children.

Another cause of his family tragedy would arise from his failure in ruling the family well. As a father, David displayed favouritism, harbouring excessive tenderness of feeling towards his son Absalom [2 Samuel 13:39] and not dealing appropriately with wrongdoing. David's failure to correct and discipline his sons would lead only to further sorrow.

David's sins and its punishment show that God's forgiveness does not remove sin's consequences in this life. This was painful chastisement upon David for taking the one "ewe lamb" [2 Samuel 12:4].
11 JUNE.part7: O give us homes built firm upon the Savior, Where Christ is Head, and Counsellor and Guide; Where ev'ry child is taught His love and favor And gives his heart to Christ, the crucified. - Barbara Beyer

12 JUNE.part4: And Amnon was so vexed, that he fell sick for his sister Tamar; for she was a virgin; and Amnon thought it hard for him to do anything to her.
12 JUNE.part5:
Amnon and Tamar were half siblings and yet he had fleshly desires for Tamar to the extent of being vexed. The Hebrew word for "vexed" shows us that Amnon was so desperate for Tamar he was distressed. The word "virgin" here means "young woman of marriageable age", thus Amnon was frustrated because she was both beautiful and sexually mature in his eyes, but he could not have her.

We recall yesterday's devotion that Amnon did not truly love Tamar but merely lusted after her. By fast forwarding to verse 15, Amnon's anger after lying with Tamar also confirms that Amnon was experiencing signs of lustfulness and not love. Incest was forbidden by God's law, but this fact did not appear to bother Amnon who was only concerned about fulfilling his own needs.

Sex is a gift from God, but this gift, as with all other gifts, can be abused. Have we often used the excuses that "we are wired this way" or "it's only natural" to justify our sins of lustfulness? Lustfulness stems from self-centredness because we only care about our own needs and not about others or what God wants for us. There is also an element of covetousness because we are tricked into believing we need to do something to fulfill that need. The devil wants us to believe that we will live far better lives if we obtain that thing or person we desire.

When temptations visit us in our minds, quickly seek God in prayer while we still can. Pray and ask God for help to overcome and run away from our lustful thoughts.
12 JUNE.part7: When temptations come, pray and persist in prayer until they go away.

13 JUNE.part4: But Amnon had a friend, whose name was Jonadab, the son of Shimeah David's brother: and Jonadab was a very subtil man.
13 JUNE.part5:
The Hebrew word for "subtil" is often translated in the Bible to mean "wise" or "cunning". The workmen who created items for use in the sanctuary [Exodus 36] were described by Moses to be "wise", meaning skillful. It is also mentioned that David was a wise and cunning man, but why is the same Hebrew word used here for Jonadab?

When we read the entire account, we notice how 'wise' a plan it really was, because the plan allowed Amnon to achieve his goal. However, wisdom and success in this world does not necessarily equate to wisdom in God's eyes. Interestingly in Deuteronomy 32:6, we see the same Hebrew word being translated as "unwise".

The Bible recognises that there is also such a thing as worldly wisdom. Sometimes it would seem such wisdom is worth heeding, but we are warned that the end of the path that worldly wisdom leads is death in the strange woman's house [Proverbs 5].

True wisdom comes from the fear of the LORD [Psalm 111:10] and it is only by seeking Him and studying His Word that we can attain the wisdom we need to navigate life on earth. When we receive advice from others, are we checking to see if it aligns with God's Word? Or is our judgement based purely on human logic or feeling or emotion?

The world is filled with wisdom, but it is in our best interests to seek godly wisdom by looking to God first and spending time with Him in His Word. So James counsels: "If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that giveth to all men liberally, and upbraideth not; and it shall be given him." [James 1:5]
13 JUNE.part7: Do we recognise the difference between godly and worldly wisdom? Or is it getting harder and harder for us to differentiate? Turn to the true source of wisdom!

14 JUNE.part4: So Amnon lay down, and made himself sick: and when the king was come to see him, Amnon said unto the king, I pray thee, let Tamar my sister come, and make me a couple of cakes in my sight, that I may eat at her hand.
14 JUNE.part5:
Lustfulness is first conceived in the mind before any physical action happens. Amnon was likely contemplating this for some time and all that was needed was a "good friend" to give him a push in the right (or wrong) direction.

Amnon had many opportunities to flee from this temptation, but he dived head in like a sheep to the slaughter. He could have told his father that he was well [v. 6]; he could have asked his servants to prevent Tamar from entering his house [v. 8]; he could have asked his servants to stay by his side [v. 9]; he could have asked for the cakes to be left outside his chamber [v. 10]; and he could have prayed for help to resist the temptation. Amnon was not at all interested to flee from it because the account tells us how smoothly the plan went. It was flawless.

Beloved, beware the sin of lustfulness because if we do not ask God for His help to curb it, it will fester and grow. It starts with an unhealthy desire in the mind, then a few glances here and there, then a need to indulge in pornography, then when pornography lacks excitement, we move on to more 'exciting' and yet unlawful things like Amnon did.

To the singles out there, marriage is not the cure for your sin of lustfulness. Lustfulness stems from self-centredness, pride and covetousness, and the only cure is to constantly remember what our Lord Jesus Christ has done for our sins. We must be open and vulnerable before God to ask Him for help to escape this great trap.
14 JUNE.part7: If you are struggling with lustfulness, find an accountability partner to share your struggles with and start praying to ask God for help to deal with it.

15 JUNE.part4: And she answered him, Nay, my brother, do not force me; for no such thing ought to be done in Israel: do not thou this folly.
15 JUNE.part5:
Right as Amnon was about to consummate his wicked plan, he received four appeals from Tamar which could have deterred him from going through with it. Tamar appealed for him to control his urges; reminded him that rape was a crime in Israel; pleaded to his conscience for she would be shamed and appealed for him to consider his reputation. Amnon could have stopped but did not. The damage has been done; might as well finish it. When we are on the verge of committing a grievous sin, the Holy Spirit within cries out for us to stop but our wicked heart spews out lies that it is too late, and we might as well go ahead. Our pride stops us from desisting.

There will always be an opportunity to resist and repent no matter how much or how far we have sinned. As long as someone reaches out with a branch, we are able to get out of the swamp, no matter how deep we have sunk. The wonder of the Cross is that the severity of our sin does not impact the effectiveness of God's forgiveness and grace towards us. His grace is ever abounding and it will cleanse every stain.

Tamar's pleas were the last line of defence for Amnon, but Amnon failed to see that and the consequence was severe. Before indulging in sin, do we listen to the pleas of our conscience and the Holy Spirit? Do we spare a thought about what our dreaded sin has done to our Saviour on the cross?
15 JUNE.part7: Let us remind ourselves of what our Saviour has done for us and how grievous our sins are, so that we may be more consciously aware of the promptings of the Holy Spirit within us.

16 JUNE.part4: Then Amnon hated her exceedingly; so that the hatred wherewith he hated her was greater than the love wherewith he had loved her. And Amnon said unto her, Arise, be gone.
16 JUNE.part5:
As a result of Tamar's resistance to his advances, Amnon's hatred toward her grew to such an extent that it overshadowed his incestuous love for her. Now his lust was fulfilled, Amnon cast her out. Tamar told Amnon that sending her away after what he had done was more evil than forcing her to lie with him. However, Amnon would not hearken to her words and commanded his servant to put her out of his room and bolt the door after her.

Amnon's feelings, his words and actions reveal that his "love" for Tamar was in fact just lust. We are commanded to love our wife as we love our own body. And no man ever hated his own flesh; but nourishes and cherishes it [Ephesians 5:28-29]. On the other hand, sinful lust, when it is satisfied, only leaves one empty, disappointed and guilty. And this often leads to hatred which in turn stirs up strife and other evil communications.

Let us be wary of worldly lusts and flee them. In our sin-cursed world, the media promotes it much, and many are enticed and drawn to them. What is lust but a desire for that which is forbidden. But the Bible warns us that "when lust hath conceived, it bringeth forth sin: and sin, when it is finished, bringeth forth death" [James 1:15]. Christians, let us, therefore, walk in the Spirit, so that we will not fulfil the lust of the flesh.
16 JUNE.part7: The wicked shall fall by his own wickedness. - Proverbs 11:5b

17 JUNE.part4: And Tamar put ashes on her head, and rent her garment of divers colours that was on her, and laid her hand on her head, and went on crying.
17 JUNE.part5:
What a horrendous evening it turned out to be. When Tamar went to Amnon's room, thinking to ease him of his sickness by caring for and feeding him, little did she realise that she would be forcibly violated. Adding insult to injury, Amnon would throw her out coldheartedly after raping her. There was nothing left for her to do but lament her fate, throw ashes on her head in grief and rent her garment of divers colours, the princess's apparel signifying a maiden's chastity and purity.

The warning in today's reading is applicable to us especially in this day and age, where the world and its media are so filled with lustful images, sounds and provocative ideas. There was a time when a woman appearing with too little clothing, and exposing too much flesh, even on the television, would be frowned upon and even censored by the authorities. Today, the same is not only prevalent, but promoted and celebrated.

Amnon's actions and the shame and pain it wrought on Tamar is a warning and reminder for us. Some things, once done cannot be undone. When we commit such a folly as Amnon did, there is no way of undoing it. There is no remedy for the shame and anguish it causes us, those around us and those who are its victims. Therefore, we must avoid such temptations at all costs.
17 JUNE.part7: Every action has consequences. Think before you act. "I counsel thee to keep the king's commandment, and that in regard of the oath of God. Be not hasty to go out of his sight: stand not in an evil thing" [Ecclesiastes 8:2-3a].

18 JUNE.part4: And Absalom spake unto his brother Amnon neither good nor bad: for Absalom hated Amnon, because he had forced his sister Tamar.
18 JUNE.part5:
Filled with shame, Tamar fled to her brother Absalom's house, where he comforted her [v. 20]. There Tamar stayed, "in solitude and sorrow, in token of her modesty and detestation of uncleanness" (Matthew Henry). Nevertheless, we observe how Absalom kept his feelings toward his brother concealed by neither speaking good nor bad of him. Yet his hatred for Amnon was real, and he would plot his revenge for his sister.

Dear Christian, the Bible has much to say about vengeance. But vengeance is not for you. The apostle Paul, in writing to the Romans, said: "Bless them which persecute you: bless and curse not." [Romans 12:14]. "Recompense to no man evil for evil ... avenge not yourselves, but rather give place unto wrath: for it is written, Vengeance is Mine; I will repay, saith the Lord" [Romans 12:17, 19]. The instruction is straightforward and clear: but it goes against every grain of human impulse and everything our natural sinful heart tells us to do, which is to avenge the wrong done against us. For Absalom, the right thing to do was to give place to God's wrath, which would surely have come to pass and allow His judgement against the wrong done to Tamar.

Let us pray and ask God for grace to forgive those who have done wrong unto us, to take hatred and the desire for revenge out of our hearts and place it in His hands instead. "Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good" [Romans 12:21].
18 JUNE.part7: Better is a dinner of herbs where love is, than a stalled ox and hatred therewith. - Proverbs 15:17

19 JUNE.part4: But when king David heard of all these things, he was very wroth.
19 JUNE.part5:
All these happenings did not go unnoticed by the king, and "he was very wroth". He heard how his daughter was violated by his son, and put out afterwards. He would have realised now how Amnon had deceived him with his feigned illness, and had gotten the king to send Tamar to his room. David also heard how Tamar now sheltered with her brother Absalom in shame, solitude and sorrow. It must have filled David with much anger and sorrow to hear all these things happening within his own family. Yet, the king did nothing to right the wrong that had been done.

As king and judge, David should have called Amnon to face the consequences of his deeds and thus alleviate Tamar's shame and sorrow and exonerate any guilt she felt. But this was not done: Amnon's crime went unpunished. David's failure left Tamar abandoned and gave Absalom motive to seek revenge against the perpetrator. David's inaction here can be likened to that of Eli, who neglected to take action against his sons for their sins in the Temple worship, thereby putting his love for them above God [1 Samuel 2:29].

It is important therefore, for those in positions of authority to do right in the eyes of the people, to stand for the oppressed and punish evil-doers. This is often not the case in our world today but as Christians, we look towards the glorious day, when our Lord Jesus Christ will return to establish His kingdom, to avenge those who have been wronged and punish the wicked.
19 JUNE.part7: If thou forbear to deliver them that are drawn unto death, and those that are ready to be slain; If thou sayest, Behold, we knew it not; doth not He that pondereth the heart consider it? and He that keepeth thy soul, doth not He know it? and shall not He render to every man according to His works? - Proverbs 24:11-12

20 JUNE.part4: And it came to pass after two full years, that Absalom had sheepshearers in Baal-hazor, which is beside Ephraim: and Absalom invited all the king's sons.
20 JUNE.part5:
Two years was a considerable time and David might have thought any wish for revenge would have by now subsided, but Absalom had not forgotten Amnon's dastardly act. It was sheep-shearing season and a time for celebration. Absalom was hosting a sheep-shearing festival at his house in Baal-hazor and Absalom sought his father's unwitting collaboration with his scheme just as Amnon had done [2 Samuel 13:5-7]. He first invited his father and his servants; but the king declined on account of the heavy expense which the reception of royalty would subject him. Absalom then scaled the invitation down to the king's sons to which David agreed.

The anger and ambition that brewed within Absalom led him to plot Amnon's murder. Likewise severe grudges harboured lead to hatred and murder: Cain murdered Abel, Herodias called for the head of John the Baptist, Joseph's brothers plotted his murder, the Pharisees plotted our Lord Jesus' death. Amnon was guilty by Levitical law but since their father did nothing, Absalom took matters into his own hands by determining the punishment for Amnon's sin. But we are told that "there is a way that seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death" [Proverbs 14:12]. Later on, Absalom's insurgence against King David ended in his own death.

There is a saying that "time heals all wounds". This implies there is no active participation on the part of man. However, the Bible exhorts us to actively think on things that are true, honest, just, pure, lovely and of good report [Philippians 4:8]. Do not let anger consume you.
20 JUNE.part7: Vengeance is Mine; I will repay, saith the Lord. - Romans 12:19b

21 JUNE.part4: Now Absalom had commanded his servants, saying, Mark ye now when Amnon's heart is merry with wine, and when I say unto you, Smite Amnon; then kill him, fear not: have not I commanded you? be courageous, and be valiant.
21 JUNE.part5:
The narrative shifts to Baal-hazor. Absalom commanded his men to kill Amnon when he least expected it and most unable to prevent the evil. Although Amnon's sin was wicked and despicable, human life is sacred and precious.

At creation " ... God created man in his own image" [Genesis 1:27] and the image of God in man remains today, though not as perfect as it was at the creation. We are reminded that even fallen sinners bear God's image [Genesis 9:6; James 3:9]. This doctrine shapes Christian ethics because it teaches that all mankind has intrinsic value. We are not merely instruments that echo back praises to God in worship. We have value in the sight of God independent of social and economic factors simply because we bear His image. Unlike animals and plants which are not made in God's image, humankind was created with the capacity to have a personal relationship with God.

And this has crucial implications on current issues such as the sanctity of human life, human rights, and bioethics. In the case of Amnon, the law prescribed that he should take Tamar as his wife [Exodus 22:16-17]. In pursuing his own agenda, Absalom took it upon himself to determine his course of action with Amnon. Absalom disregarded God's prescribed law, and ignored the wisdom of God and the sanctity of human life. Human life has transcendent value in God's eyes and must always be valued and respected as such.
21 JUNE.part7: May the words of the children's song take on a deeper meaning, "Red and yellow, black and white, they are precious in His sight."

22 JUNE.part4: Then the king arose, and tare his garments, and lay on the earth; and all his servants stood by with their clothes rent.
22 JUNE.part5:
As soon as Amnon is dead, the narrative returns us to David's court to attend the news arriving from Absalom's house. The first report claimed that all the king's sons were dead. There were no survivors and therefore no successors to David's throne except Absalom. No parent wants to outlive their children, let alone have their children die prematurely. Although the first report was exaggerated and only Amnon was dead, David apparently still believed it to be true [v. 32] for he immediately initiated the mourning rituals for his dead sons.

David would feel very much like Job when he learned that all of his children had been killed [Job 1:18-20]. It is like the death of his son with Bathsheba [2 Samuel 12:13-14]. It brings to our attention the deep sorrow one faces upon the loss of a loved one. It reminds us to show sympathy and compassion when our neighbour is undergoing such a sorrowful event in his life.

Demonstrating compassion can be accomplished in a number of ways. It may simply be in the form of your presence. Just like David's servants [v. 31] and Job's friends [Job 2:11-13], may we be found alongside our neighbours comforting them in their time of loss. It may be through intercessory prayer with and for them. It may be expressed by means of material provisions and physical help. When we do these things, we are conformed more to the image of our Lord Jesus Who Himself looked at the sick and suffering of His time and "was moved with compassion" [Matthew 14:14].
22 JUNE.part7: Rejoice with them that do rejoice, and weep with them that weep. - Romans 12:15

23 JUNE.part4: Now therefore let not my lord the king take the thing to his heart, to think that all the king's sons are dead: for Amnon only is dead.
23 JUNE.part5:
The misinformation that all of David's sons were dead provides Jonadab an opportunity to speak, not only to rectify the earlier report, but also to persuade the king of Absalom's singular motivation. Remember that Jonadab is the same person who helped Amnon commit his vile sin. The text does not reveal how Jonadab knew Absalom's plans, perhaps it was only his theory, or perhaps he had overheard Absalom muttering threats.

Although Jonadab was an accessory to the crime that fueled Absalom's vengeance, he took no responsibility. Instead, he used it as an opportunity to gain influence to further his own ends. Jonadab knew what Amnon had in mind with his sister, Tamar, but did nothing to stop it. It appears Jonadab knew Absalom was carrying a grudge, but he also did nothing to prevent Amnon's murder. And now he is found by David's side showing apparent sympathy in consoling him.

This reminds us to be careful of the company that we keep. Paul exhorted: "Be not deceived: evil communications corrupt good manners" [1 Corinthians 15:33]. We should surround ourselves with friends that care for us, not people who want to use us. Like Jonadab, Delilah deceived Samson and did not truly care for him. Keeping company with such will only lead to our destruction [Proverbs 13:20]. This proverb also encourages us to surround ourselves with wise men. Seeking out godly men and women full of biblical wisdom and morals will make one wise.
23 JUNE.part7: Dear God, give me discernment in choosing the company that I keep, and send me godly company that will help me grow more and more like our Lord Jesus.

24 JUNE.part4: And it came to pass, as soon as he had made an end of speaking, that, behold, the king's sons came, and lifted up their voice and wept: and the king also and all his servants wept very sore.
24 JUNE.part5:
We are presented with a sorrowful scene today. David's great shock at the false report of all his sons being murdered was replaced by heart-stopping suspense when Jonadab reported that only Amnon had been killed. The great rush of relief at the arrival of the king's grieving sons was quickly followed by the terrible certainty that Amnon had been murdered - and by no lesser than his own brother, Absalom.

As David was being rocked by the whirlwind of emotions, he may have recalled God's pronouncement that the sword would never leave his house [2 Samuel 12:10]. David may have recalled his own ill-example to his children and his murder of innocent Uriah, brought about by his base passions. The consequence? An innocent infant had died after birth. Now years later, his eldest son Amnon was dead, and his third son Absalom had fled into exile.

When Amnon sinned grossly against his own sister, David as the head of the house was "wroth" but kept silent. David's passivity as a father and ruler made way for evil counsellors like Jonadab, whose words to David clearly showed that he had known for some time of Absalom's ill-intentions toward Amnon. We will see David continue to keep his silence after Absalom murdered his brother, and this would lead to even more waywardness in his household in the future.

Rulers and parents who show an unwise partiality in not adequately chastising evil doers only defer the day of trouble and increase its sorrows.
24 JUNE.part7: Let not sin therefore reign in your mortal body, that ye should obey it in the lusts thereof. - Romans 6:12

25 JUNE.part4: But Absalom fled, and went to Talmai, the son of Ammihud, king of Geshur. And David mourned for his son every day.
25 JUNE.part5:
Absalom fled to the safety of his mother's father, the son of Ammihud, king of Geshur - a man called Talmai. There he hoped to find protection, safety, and he sought refuge for three years.

David mourned bitterly for Amnon. But even that grief would fade with time and he once more longed for Absalom to return. As Matthew Henry expressed, "Time wore off David's grief for Amnon, but it also wore off entirely too much of his detestation of Absalom's terrible sin". Instead of loathing Absalom as a murderer, David now longed to find him. His longing would soon lead to Absalom being able to return home which led to a string of tragedy, rebellion, and sin.

David's grief may reveal to us the depth of a father's love over the loss of a son and his deep regret for his own personal failures, which led the way to many family and national tragedies. Yet David's failure to exercise his duty as ruler and father to chastise Absalom may well have been the reason for Absalom's rebellion later.

A father's love is not an unwise love that turns a blind eye to a child's every wrong and meets his sin only with affection. That is not the love of God. God desires that we are set apart for Him and relinquish sin. He longs not just for us to return to Him, but that we whom He has chosen before the foundation of the world, should be holy and blameless before him [Ephesians 1:4].
25 JUNE.part7: For I am the Lord your God: ye shall therefore sanctify yourselves, and ye shall be holy. - Leviticus 11:44a

26 JUNE.part4: And the soul of king David longed to go forth unto Absalom: for he was comforted concerning Amnon, seeing he was dead.
26 JUNE.part5:
It is not difficult to put ourselves in the king's shoes. The sword had not only cut through his house [2 Samuel 12:10]; it had thrust deep into his heart. When Amnon was killed, David effectively lost two sons - one to death and another to exile.

But time heals. After three years, David had gotten over the incident. Some commentaries have pointed out that the verse could also be translated "David ceased to go against Absalom". The conclusion is the same - the heat of the incident had cooled - and perhaps some in the king's court might even feel that the time for reconciliation had come.

In fact, the matter was far from settled. David's lack of discipline toward his son Absalom - now the next in line to the throne - would lead to disastrous complications. It would cause David more trouble in the days to come. Absalom's unpunished transgression and unchecked pride would cause him to grow in arrogance. Even if he had continued to be in exile, he was an easy tool to be manipulated by opportunists who wished to usurp power from whoever was on the throne.

Having been king for so many years, David could have seen this impending threat, but he allowed his emotions to get the better of him. In the deepest recesses of his heart, he longed for this beloved son. As king, he was duty and morally bound to exact punishment for the murder especially of a prince, yet as a father, he was about to condone the abhorrent behaviour of his son. This marks the beginning of disaster.
26 JUNE.part7: He that spareth his rod hateth his son: but he that loveth him chasteneth him betimes. - Proverbs 13:24

27 JUNE.part4: Now Joab the son of Zeruiah perceived that the king's heart was toward Absalom.
27 JUNE.part5:
In the king's court, some perhaps could perceive a reconciliation between David and his son. And though Absalom seemed to have lost David's favour, he was still after all be an heir and next in the line of succession. It would take an opportunist to seize this chance of ingratiating himself to advance his own interests. And such a person was none other than David's army commander, Joab.

Joab is the ultimate example of the opportunistic pragmatist. His actions were not guided by morals or principles, but motivated by self-interest. His life history of violence and immorality was clear. In 2 Samuel 3:27, his murder of Saul's commander, Abner, under the guise of avenging his brother, had removed the greatest rival in his career path then. Though a great help to the king in their battles [1 Chronicles 11:6-9; 19:9-13], he was once also David's worst accessory to sin [2 Samuel 11].

Now in the case of Absalom, getting this estranged son back for David would open many career options for him. But later when it turned out Absalom had failed (and given that Absalom trusted and made Amasa his commander - 2 Samuel 17:25), it was also Joab who would kill both Absalom [2 Samuel 18:9-15 - explicitly against David's order] and Amasa [2 Samuel 20:8-12 - conveniently in the chaos of another revolt].

By 2 Samuel 20:23, Joab was the most powerful man in Israel after David - so powerful that David was afraid to act against him and had instead beseeched his successor Solomon to kill him [1 Kings 2:5-6]. His death would be a most tragic one [1 Kings 2:28-33].
27 JUNE.part7: All the ways of a man are clean in his own eyes; but the LORD weigheth the spirits. Commit thy works unto the LORD, and thy thoughts shall be established. The LORD hath made all things for Himself: yea, even the wicked for the day of evil. - Proverbs 16:2-4

28 JUNE.part4: Now Joab the son of Zeruiah perceived that the king's heart was toward Absalom.
28 JUNE.part5:
Commentators on this verse vary widely in their reading of David's attitude towards Absalom at this point of time. Some think that "toward" in this verse should be translated as "against", as this would better account for why Joab needed to come out with a plan to convince David to recall Absalom, and also explain why David refused to meet Absalom for another two years even when the latter was back.

Yet we must also understand David's position. As king, David needed to show an example to his people. If he had welcomed his own son back with open arms, without any retribution whatsoever, it would make it difficult for him to judge any murder in future, especially one involving fratricide. But like most fathers, it is also "natural" that he has a soft spot for his son, especially one as beautiful as Absalom.

We often use "natural" as an excuse to condone wrongdoing. "He shouldn't have done it, but given the situation, it is natural for him to do that." Granted when it comes to judging and meting out discipline, we can make room for exceptions that call for compassion, but we need to examine our motives, and be impartial. We should not allow our hearts to lead us astray - especially in the training of our children.

It is the same in our Christian walk. There may be compromises which the world deems quite "natural" but they may go against what God has taught. And if we acquiesce, often our deceitful heart will whisper that it is alright to close an eye to sin. In times like these, gird up our loins and stand firm. Guard our hearts and follow God's way.
28 JUNE.part7: Now no chastening for the present seemeth to be joyous, but grievous: nevertheless afterward it yieldeth the peaceable fruit of righteousness unto them which are exercised thereby. - Hebrews 12:11

29 JUNE.part4: And Joab sent to Tekoah, and fetched thence a wise woman, and said unto her, I pray thee, feign thyself to be a mourner, and put on now mourning apparel, and anoint not thyself with oil, but be as a woman that had a long time mourned for the dead:
29 JUNE.part5:
The king harbours a soft spot for his wayward son. Yet perhaps regarding public opinion, he did not make the call to get him back. Seeing this, the opportunist Joab grabbed this chance to ingratiate the king and perhaps also his presumptive heir. This would place him in a good political position.

Joab sent for a woman in Tekoah, which was at the border of the wilderness southeast of Jerusalem. He must have heard the reputation of this cunning woman, or even used her in some of his past conspiracies. But she was someone he trusted to understand and deliver what Joab wanted done.

She would make great pretence as a mourner appealing to the king. And "Joab put the words in her mouth" [v. 3], telling her exactly what to say. The story spun would bring to David's mind the dilemma he himself faced, from which she would then present her remonstration.

The element of guile aside, this plan was a tactful one, which tells us of Joab's cleverness. The method of entreating the king in a gentle manner is not wrong. We could even say a similar strategy was used by prophet Nathan in confronting David with his sin [2 Samuel 12], except he had used a parable, not a lie. But it is the intention that makes all the difference. Nathan was used by God to rebuke David, whereas Joab, acting for his own interests, sought the help of a deceitful woman to manipulate David into a decision he would later regret.
29 JUNE.part7: But if ye have bitter envying and strife in your hearts, glory not, and lie not against the truth. This wisdom descendeth not from above, but is earthly, sensual, devilish. For where envying and strife is, there is confusion and every evil work. - James 3:14-16

30 JUNE.part4: And when the woman of Tekoah spake to the king, she fell on her face to the ground, and did obeisance, and said, Help, O king.
30 JUNE.part5:
The woman of Tekoah presented her case, paying obeisance to the king. Her intention was to remonstrate, and she began with a moving expression of seeming humility and submission, pretending to seek the king's help.

The fabricated case was made to touch the heart of its hearer. She was a widow with two sons, and one slew the other. The whole family wanted the life of the murderer, according to levitical law. But this remaining son was her only support on earth, and the only son to continue the line of her husband. This then might be a case that calls for compassion and mercy.

The analogy the woman presented was apt and vivid: killing her son would "quench my coal which is left" [v. 7] - her flame of life was already reduced to simmering embers, and killing him would snuff it out completely.

The situation painted by the woman was not exactly that faced by David. Perhaps it was intended so David would not realise prematurely the woman's motive. But it did soften and prime his heart, suggesting to him there might be a way out of his dilemma between justice and family. All he needed then was for someone to justify his actions to recall his son, after which he hoped that no one would bring up the incident again. Granted that David would refuse to see Absalom for another two years, still they could be reconciled later. But Absalom would get away with a grievous crime, with no proper correction and no accountability.
30 JUNE.part7: Foolishness is bound in the heart of a child; but the rod of correction shall drive it far from him. - Proverbs 22:15
